subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Federal holiday” means, as to each corresponding legal holiday, the date that the federal government designates for observance of the holiday.
“Optional bank holiday” means a day on which a banking institution is authorized to be closed.

section.text: For the purposes of this subtitle, the operation of an automated teller machine or the conduct of internal operations by a banking institution does not constitute being open for business.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a banking institution shall be open for business on each day during the year except for the days on which the banking institution is required or authorized by this subtitle to be closed.
The Commissioner may approve the operation of a branch that is open for business fewer days than described in subsection (a) of this section if the Commissioner determines that:

paragraph.text: The branch will serve a customer base or community that has unique banking needs;
At least 1 other branch of the banking institution is open for business as described in subsection (a) of this section; and
The operation of the branch will not be detrimental to the public interest or to banking institutions.

section.text: Each banking institution shall be closed on Sunday.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, each banking institution shall be closed on the following legal holidays:

subparagraph.text: New Year’s Day;
Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.’s Birthday;
Washington’s Birthday;
Good Friday;
Memorial Day;
Independence Day;
Labor Day;
Columbus Day;
Veterans’ Day;
Thanksgiving Day; and
Christmas Day.
When a legal holiday differs from the corresponding federal holiday, a banking institution:

sub-subparagraph.text: May be closed on both holidays; and
Shall be closed on one of the holidays.

subparagraph.text: When there is no corresponding federal holiday for a legal holiday listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection, a banking institution:

sub-subparagraph.text: May be closed on the legal holiday; or
May remain open on the legal holiday.

paragraph.text: Each legal holiday that is not listed in subsection (a) of this section is an optional bank holiday.
When, as to any optional bank holiday, the legal holiday differs from the corresponding federal holiday, a banking institution may be closed on:

subparagraph.text: Both holidays;
The legal holiday; or
The federal holiday.

subsection.text: Saturday is an optional bank holiday.
A banking institution that opens for business on Saturday may close at noon.
In this section, “emergency” has the meaning stated in § 14-307 of the Public Safety Article.

paragraph.text: If the Governor proclaims that an emergency exists in a political subdivision and designates days for the general cessation of business in the subdivision, each banking office that is located within the subdivision shall be closed on those days.
If the Governor proclaims that an emergency exists in a political subdivision, the Governor may designate days on which each banking office that is located within the subdivision may be closed.
If the Governor proclaims that an emergency exists as to a particular banking office, that office may be closed on those days that the Governor designates.
When the Governor authorizes, but does not require, the banking institution to be closed, the chairman of its board of directors or its president shall decide whether to close or remain open.

If an emergency exists and affects a banking institution and if it is not practical to obtain a proclamation from the Governor before closing the affected institution, the chairman of its board of directors or its president:

subparagraph.text: May close the banking institution; and
As soon as possible, but within 24 hours after the closing, shall notify the Governor of the reasons for the closing.

paragraph.text: A banking institution may be closed under this subsection until the earlier of:

subparagraph.text: Issuance by the Governor of a proclamation that relates to the emergency closing;
Notice to the banking institution that the Governor will not issue a proclamation;
Reopening of the banking institution by the chairman of its board of directors or by its president; or
5 p.m. on the third day after the closing, except for Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays.

section.text: A banking institution shall be open for business or shall be closed on optional bank holidays, as the directors of the banking institution may specify by resolution.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner believes that a director or officer of a banking institution has engaged in an unsafe or unsound banking practice, the Commissioner shall send a warning to the director or officer.

paragraph.text: If the Commissioner finds that the director or officer has continued to engage in the unsafe or unsound practice, the Commissioner may report the facts to the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation and the Attorney General.
A copy of the report shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, bearing a postmark from the United States Postal Service, to each director of the banking institution.

After giving the officer or director an opportunity to be heard, if the Commissioner finds that the unsafe or unsound practice continued after the warning, the Commissioner with the approval of the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation may remove the officer or director.
A copy of the removal order shall be served on the individual removed and the banking institution.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner believes that a banking institution or any of its directors, officers, trustees, managers, agents, or employees has violated any provision of this article that relates to the institution, the Commissioner immediately shall report the violation to the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, who shall ask the Attorney General to take the appropriate steps to institute a prosecution for the violation.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall send a warning to a director or officer of a banking institution who the Commissioner believes has violated any provision of this article that relates to the institution.
If, after the warning, the director or officer continues to violate the law, the director or officer may be removed as provided in § 5-801 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Unless another penalty specifically is provided elsewhere in this article, any banking institution and any director, officer, trustee, manager, agent, or employee of a banking institution who violates any provision of this article that relates to the institution is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $3,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.

An officer, director, or employee of a bank, trust company, or savings bank may not willfully and knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or false entry in its records or, with the intent to deceive a person authorized to examine the affairs of the bank, trust company, or savings bank, sign or exhibit false records.

Any officer, director, or employee who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a felony and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 10 years or both.
An officer or employee of a banking institution may not accept a deposit knowing that the institution is insolvent.
An officer or employee who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment in the State Penitentiary for a period not exceeding 3 years.

A person may not willfully make, circulate, or send to another any untrue statement that is derogatory to the financial condition or affects the solvency or financial standing of any bank, trust company, or savings bank doing business in this State or counsel, aid, procure, or induce another to make, circulate, or send to another such a statement.
Any person who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 3 years.

Except for a bank, trust company, savings bank, or savings and loan association that is authorized to do business in this State, a person may not use any name, title, or other words that represent that the person is authorized to do the business of banking in this State.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection the following terms have the meanings indicated.

sub-subparagraph.text: “Bank” means any bank, trust company, savings bank, or savings and loan association that is authorized to do business in this State, and any subsidiary or affiliate of the entity.
“Bank” includes any Farm Credit System institution in this State.

subparagraph.text: “Name” means the name, trade name, trademark, service mark, logo, or tagline used by a bank to identify itself.

paragraph.text: Except with the consent of the bank, a person may not use the name of a bank or any term or design that is similar to the name of a bank in any marketing material provided to another person or in any solicitation of another person in a manner that may cause a reasonable person to be confused, mistaken, or deceived that the marketing material or solicitation:

subparagraph.text: Originated from the bank;
Originated from someone affiliated, connected, or associated with the bank;
Is approved or sponsored by the bank; or
Is the responsibility of the bank.

subsection.text: In addition to any other remedies a bank may have under any other provision of law, a bank that is affected by a violation of subsection (b) of this section may bring an action against the person that committed the violation to recover:

paragraph.text: Actual damages sustained as a result of the violation;
Either:

subparagraph.text: All profits attributable to the violation; or
$1,000 for each violation; and

paragraph.text: Court costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.

subsection.text: Any person who violates subsection (a) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $3,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.
A banking institution may not:

paragraph.text: Issue an advertisement or make a representation that is false, misleading, or deceptive;
Impose as a condition for a loan any restriction on obtaining credit, property, or service from a competitor unless the restriction is reasonably necessary to secure the loan;
Impose as a condition for a service any restriction on obtaining credit, property, or service from a competitor; or
Engage in an act or practice that is anticompetitive, unfair, deceptive, or injurious to public interest.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may further define specific acts or practices that are anticompetitive, unfair, deceptive, or injurious to the public interest.

A banking institution and any director, officer, trustee, manager, agent, or employee of a banking institution who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $3,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.
The Commissioner may order any banking institution to cease and desist from:

paragraph.text: An unsafe or unsound banking practice;
A practice that is injurious to the public interest; or
A violation of a law, rule, or regulation that relates to the Commissioner’s supervision of the institution.

subsection.text: To protect depositors, stockholders, or the public, the Commissioner may include in a cease and desist order a restriction on the withdrawal of money from any banking institution.
The Commissioner may include in a cease and desist order a requirement that the officers or directors of a banking institution act affirmatively to correct any violation or practice.

paragraph.text: Before a cease and desist order takes effect, the Commissioner shall give the banking institution an opportunity for a hearing.
Notice of the hearing shall be given and the hearing shall be held in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner determines that the violation or practice under subsection (a) of this section requires immediate action to protect depositors, stockholders, or the public, the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: May issue a cease and desist order that is effective on service; and
Shall give the banking institution an opportunity for a hearing to rescind the order.

subsection.text: After notice and a hearing, the Commissioner may assess a civil penalty against a banking institution that the Commissioner determines has:

paragraph.text: Violated a cease and desist order issued by the Commissioner under § 5–808 of this subtitle; or
Engaged in:

subparagraph.text: An unsafe or unsound banking practice; or
A practice that is injurious to the public interest.

subsection.text: The civil penalty may not exceed:

paragraph.text: $1,000 per violation; and
$1,000 per violation for each day that the violation continues.
A civil penalty shall be assessed by written notice of assessment served on the person to be assessed.
The notice of assessment shall state the:

subparagraph.text: Amount of the civil penalty;
Legal authority for the assessment; and
Matters of fact or law constituting the grounds for the assessment.

paragraph.text: The notice of assessment shall constitute a final order for purposes of judicial review pursuant to § 10–221 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: In determining the amount of the civil penalty to be assessed, the Commissioner shall consider:

paragraph.text: The seriousness of the violation;
The good faith of the violator;
The violator’s history of previous violations;
The deleterious effect of the violation on the public and the banking industry;
The assets of the violator; and
Any other factors relevant to the determination of the civil penalty.
A civil penalty assessed under this section shall be due and payable within 30 days after the Commissioner issues the notice of assessment.
The Commissioner may reduce or set aside a civil penalty.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall pay all civil penalties collected under this section into the General Fund of the State.
In this section, “extraordinary circumstances” means a situation presenting specific concerns about the prompt withdrawal of money from, or the safety and soundness of, a banking institution.

In extraordinary circumstances and with the consent of the banking institution, the Commissioner may close to the public a hearing concerning the assessment of a civil penalty, an order to cease and desist, or any other formal enforcement action by the Commissioner.

section.text: On application by the Commissioner, a court of competent jurisdiction may issue an injunction to restrain a banking institution from:

paragraph.text: An unsafe or unsound banking practice;
A practice that is injurious to the public interest; or
A violation of a law, rule, or regulation that relates to the Commissioner’s supervision of the institution.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Acquire” means:

paragraph.text: For one bank holding company to merge or consolidate with another bank holding company;
For a bank holding company to assume direct or indirect ownership or control of:

subparagraph.text: More than 5 percent of any class of voting shares of another bank holding company or a bank; or
All or substantially all of the assets of another bank holding company or a bank; or

paragraph.text: To take any other action that results in the direct or indirect control by a bank holding company of another bank holding company or a bank.

subsection.text: “Affiliate” has the meaning stated in § 5-401 of this title.
“Bank” has the meaning stated in § 2(c) of the Bank Holding Company Act.
“Bank holding company”:

paragraph.text: Has the meaning stated in § 2(a) of the Bank Holding Company Act; and
Unless the context requires otherwise, includes:

subparagraph.text: A Maryland bank holding company;
An out-of-state bank holding company;
A foreign bank holding company; and
A corporation or other entity that becomes a bank holding company by making an acquisition under this subtitle.

subsection.text: “Bank Holding Company Act” means the federal Bank Holding Company Act of 1956.
“Bank supervisory agency” means:

paragraph.text: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, and the Office of Foreign Assets Control, and any successor to these agencies;
Any agency of another state with primary responsibility for chartering and supervising banks; and
Any agency of a foreign country with primary responsibility for chartering and supervising banks.

subsection.text: “Control” has the meaning stated in § 2(a) of the Bank Holding Company Act.
“Deposit”:

paragraph.text: With respect to any bank holding company other than a foreign bank holding company, has the meaning stated in 12 U.S.C. § 1813(l); and
With respect to a foreign bank holding company, has the meaning stated in the law of the country in which the holding company is organized or incorporated.

subsection.text: “Foreign bank holding company” means a bank holding company with its principal place of business outside the United States.
“Insured depository institution” means any financial institution the deposits of which are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
“Maryland bank” means a bank that is:

paragraph.text: Organized under Title 3 or Title 4 of this article; or
Organized under federal law and having its main office in this State.

subsection.text: “Maryland bank holding company” means a bank holding company that:

paragraph.text: Had its principal place of business in this State on the later of July 1, 1966 or the date on which the company became a bank holding company; and
Is not controlled by a bank holding company other than a Maryland bank holding company.
“Out-of-state bank holding company” means a bank holding company that is not a Maryland bank holding company.
“Out-of-state bank holding company” includes a foreign bank holding company.

subsection.text: “Principal place of business” means the jurisdiction in which the total deposits of a bank holding company’s bank subsidiaries are the greatest.
“State” means any state, territory, or other possession of the United States, including the District of Columbia.
“Subsidiary” has the meaning stated in § 2(d) of the Bank Holding Company Act.

section.text: This subtitle sets forth the conditions under which a bank holding company may acquire a Maryland bank or a Maryland bank holding company.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise expressly permitted by federal law, no bank holding company may acquire a Maryland bank holding company or a Maryland bank without the approval of the Commissioner.
The prohibition in subsection (a) of this section shall not apply where the acquisition is made:

paragraph.text: Solely for the purpose of facilitating an acquisition otherwise permitted under this subtitle;
In a transaction arranged by the Commissioner or another bank supervisory agency to prevent the insolvency or closing of the acquired bank; or

In a transaction in which a bank forms its own bank holding company, if the ownership rights of the former bank shareholders are substantially similar to those of the shareholders of the new holding company.

subsection.text: In a transaction for which the Commissioner’s approval is not required under this section, the parties shall give written notice to the Commissioner at least 15 days before the effective date of the acquisition.
A bank holding company that proposes to make an acquisition under this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: File with the Commissioner an application in the form that the Commissioner requires;
Pay to the Commissioner an application fee of $1,500; and
Submit proof that the applicant has complied with all public notice and publication requirements applicable under the Bank Holding Company Act.

subsection.text: To the extent consistent with the effective discharge of the Commissioner’s responsibilities, the forms established under this subtitle for application, notice, and reporting shall conform to those established under the Bank Holding Company Act.
In deciding whether to approve an application under § 5-904 of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall consider whether the acquisition:

paragraph.text: May be detrimental to the safety and soundness of the Maryland bank or Maryland bank holding company to be acquired; or
May result in an undue concentration of resources or a substantial reduction of competition in the State.

subsection.text: Except as provided in this section, the Commissioner may not approve an acquisition if on consummation of the transaction the applicant, including any insured depository institution affiliate of the applicant, would control 30 percent or more of the total amount of deposits of insured depository institutions in the State.
The Commissioner may by regulation adopt a procedure by which the 30 percent deposit limit may be waived for good cause.
The Commissioner shall decide whether to approve an application under § 5-904 of this subtitle within 60 days of receipt of a completed application.
An application shall be deemed approved if the Commissioner takes no action on the application within the time limits specified in this section.

To the extent specified by the Commissioner by regulation or written request, each bank holding company that controls a Maryland bank or a Maryland bank holding company shall submit to the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: Copies of reports filed for the preceding calendar year with a bank supervisory agency by each Maryland bank controlled by the bank holding company; and
A report specifying as of the end of the preceding calendar year, for each branch of each Maryland bank controlled by the bank holding company:

subparagraph.text: The location; and
The amount of deposits held.

subsection.text: The reports specified in subsection (a) of this section:

paragraph.text: May consist of a copy of a report filed with another bank supervisory agency that contains substantially similar information; and
May not be requested by the Commissioner unless the Commissioner determines that the information is not available from another bank supervisory agency.

subsection.text: At the request of the Commissioner, to the extent permitted by applicable State or federal law, each bank holding company that controls a Maryland bank or a Maryland bank holding company shall provide to the Commissioner copies of reports of examination prepared by any bank supervisory agency in connection with the examination of any Maryland bank.

section.text: The Commissioner may enforce the provisions of this subtitle by any appropriate action in the circuit courts of the State, including actions for injunctive relief and for divestment.

subsection.text: In order to carry out the purposes of this article, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: Adopt regulations; and
Subject to subsection (b) of this section, enter into cooperative or information–sharing agreements with any other bank supervisory agency.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner receives a record from a bank supervisory agency under a cooperative or an information–sharing agreement authorized by subsection (a)(2) of this section and the bank supervisory agency expressly retains ownership of the record, either in writing or by law or regulation, the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: May not disclose the record to any person that requests the record under §§ 10–611 through 10–628 of the State Government Article; and

Shall forward the request for the record to the bank supervisory agency that owns the record for processing in accordance with the laws or regulations governing disclosure of the bank supervisory agency’s records.

section.text: If any provision of this subtitle or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid for any reason in a court of competent jurisdiction, the invalidity does not affect other provisions or any other application of this subtitle that can be given effect without the invalid provision or application.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Affiliate” means any company that controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with another company.
“Bank” has the meaning stated in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act, 12 U.S.C. § 1813(a)(1).
“Bank supervisory agency” means:

paragraph.text: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, or any successor to these agencies; or
An agency of another state with primary responsibility for chartering and supervising banks.
“Branch” means a bank office open to the public at which deposits are received, checks are paid, or money is lent.
“Branch” includes a mobile branch or other special-purpose facility that performs a function of a branch.
“Branch” does not include an automated teller machine as defined in § 1-401 of this article.

subsection.text: “Commercial activities” means activities in which a bank holding company, a financial holding company, a national bank, or a national bank financial subsidiary may not engage under federal law.
“De novo branch” means a branch of an out-of-state bank or banking institution that:

paragraph.text: Is originally established by the out-of-state bank or banking institution as a branch; and
Does not become a branch of the out-of-state bank or banking institution as a result of:

subparagraph.text: The acquisition by the out-of-state bank or banking institution of an insured depository institution or a branch of an insured depository institution; or
The conversion, merger, or consolidation of an insured depository institution or a branch of an insured depository institution.

subsection.text: “Home state” means:

paragraph.text: As to a national banking association, the state in which its main office is located; and
As to a state-chartered bank, the state by which it is chartered.

subsection.text: “Home state regulator” means the agency in a bank’s home state with primary responsibility for chartering and regulating banks.
“Host state” means a state, other than the home state of a bank, in which the bank maintains or seeks to establish a branch.
“Insured depository institution” means any financial institution the deposits of which are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
“National banking association” means a bank chartered under the National Bank Act.
“Other-state bank” means a bank chartered and primarily regulated by another state.
“Out-of-state bank” means:

paragraph.text: A national banking association with its main office in a state other than this State; or
An other-state bank.

section.text: This subtitle sets forth the conditions under which:

paragraph.text: An out-of-state bank may establish branches in this State; and
A banking institution may establish branches within or outside this State.

subsection.text: A banking institution or an out–of–state bank may establish a branch in this State by:

paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, opening a de novo branch;
Purchasing an existing branch from a bank or an insured depository institution; or
Converting former headquarters or retaining former branches following:

subparagraph.text: The purchase of all or substantially all of the assets of a bank or an insured depository institution; or
A merger or a consolidation with a bank or an insured depository institution.

subsection.text: An out–of–state bank may establish a de novo branch in this State under subsection (a)(1) of this section only if the home state of the out–of–state bank allows a banking institution to open a de novo branch in its state.
A banking institution or an out–of–state bank may not establish or maintain a branch in this State on the premises or property of an affiliate if the affiliate engages in commercial activities.

section.text: A banking institution may establish a branch in another state by any means permitted by the laws of that state or by federal law.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a banking institution that proposes to establish a branch in this State or in another state shall:

paragraph.text: File with the Commissioner, at least 30 days before the intended opening date, a notice of intention to open a branch; and
Submit to the Commissioner any information the Commissioner requires in order to evaluate the proposed branch.

subsection.text: A well–capitalized banking institution with a composite CAMELS rating of one or two may establish a branch in this State by filing with the Commissioner an expedited notice, in the form that the Commissioner requires, at least 30 days before the intended opening date.
Subject to subsection (b) of this section, in deciding whether to approve a branch of a banking institution, the Commissioner shall consider:

paragraph.text: If the branch is to be established in this State, whether the establishment of the branch will promote the public convenience;
Whether the applicant has sufficient capital to support the branch; and
Whether the applicant is generally operating in compliance with the provisions of this article.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a well–capitalized banking institution with a composite CAMELS rating of one or two may open a branch in this State without the approval of the Commissioner 30 days after filing an expedited notice for the proposed branch under § 5–1005(b) of this subtitle.
The Commissioner may:

subparagraph.text: Require the submission of additional information regarding the proposed establishment of a branch during the 30–day period that the expedited notice is pending; and

Prohibit the establishment of the branch within the 30–day period if the Commissioner determines that establishment of the branch is not consistent with the standards set forth in subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall decide whether to approve the establishment of a branch of a banking institution within 30 days of receipt of the notice specified in § 5-1005 of this subtitle.
A branch shall be deemed approved if the Commissioner takes no action on the notice within the time limit specified in this section.

A banking institution that establishes a branch in another state may exercise at that branch all powers and rights permitted to banks in that state unless the Commissioner determines that the exercise of a power or right would threaten the safety and soundness of the banking institution.

An other-state bank that establishes a branch in this State may exercise at the branch all powers and rights permitted to banking institutions in this State notwithstanding any other law of this State to the contrary, unless that bank’s home state regulator determines that the exercise of a power or right would threaten the safety and soundness of the other-state bank.

Any person authorized by a law of this State to engage in business with banks located in this State, including the making of deposits, is authorized to engage in the same business with an other-state bank at that other-state bank’s branch in this State.

Subject to § 5-1012 of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall have the power to examine every branch of an other-state bank located in this State for the same purposes and to the same extent as the Commissioner may examine a branch of a banking institution.

The Commissioner may enter into agreements with bank supervisory agencies regarding the scope, timing, coordination, and frequency of examinations and other supervisory matters, including the sharing of information obtained through examination of other-state banks that maintain branches in this State.

Supervisory and examination fees related to the Commissioner’s oversight of Maryland branches of other-state banks and branches of banking institutions in other states may be imposed and shall be calculated in the manner agreed to between the Commissioner and the home state regulators.

Subject to § 5-1012 of this subtitle, if the Commissioner finds that a branch of an other-state bank in this State is being operated in an unsafe or unsound manner or there is any violation of Maryland law by the branch of the other-state bank, the Commissioner may undertake enforcement actions as otherwise authorized under provisions in this article governing banking institutions.
The Commissioner may enter into joint enforcement actions with other bank supervisory agencies having concurrent jurisdiction over an other-state bank that has a branch in this State.

section.text: Subject to § 5-1012 of this subtitle, the Commissioner may require a bank that maintains a branch in this State to submit to the Commissioner its consolidated reports of condition and income in the form specified by the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council.

With respect to the supervision, enforcement, and reporting requirements of §§ 5-1009, 5-1010, and 5-1011 of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall act primarily in cooperation with the home state regulator or federal regulator of the affected out-of-state bank.

subsection.text: Except as provided in this section, the Commissioner may not approve a transaction resulting in the establishment of a branch or branches by a bank, other than a de novo branch, if on consummation of the transaction the applicant, including any insured depository institution affiliate of the applicant, would control 30 percent or more of the total amount of deposits of insured depository institutions in this State.
The Commissioner may by regulation adopt a procedure by which the 30 percent deposit limit may be waived for good cause.
An out-of-state bank that proposes to establish a branch in this State:

paragraph.text: Shall qualify under § 7-203 of the Corporations and Associations Article to do business in the State as a foreign corporation; and
Within 15 days of filing a branch application with the appropriate bank supervisory agency, shall provide the Commissioner with a copy of the branch application.

subsection.text: An out-of-state bank that does not have a branch in this State on September 29, 1995, may not establish a branch in this State before June 1, 1997, unless the laws of that bank’s home state would permit a banking institution to establish a branch in that state under substantially similar conditions as those imposed by this subtitle.
An out-of-state bank that has a branch in this State may establish additional branches in this State to the same extent as a banking institution or to the extent otherwise permitted by federal law.

section.text: If any provision of this subtitle or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid for any reason in a court of competent jurisdiction, the invalidity does not affect other provisions or any other application of this subtitle that can be given effect without the invalid provision or application.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Acquire” means to assume ownership or control, directly or indirectly, of any voting shares of, interest in, or all or a substantial portion of the assets and liabilities, including, unless otherwise determined in writing by the Director of the State of Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund Corporation to be in the best financial interest of the Fund, all savings accounts liabilities that are insured by the Fund, to the extent of the insurance, and liabilities to the State, of the following institutions:

paragraph.text: A savings and loan association;
A newly-formed commercial bank chartered to consummate a transaction with a savings and loan association under this subtitle; or
A commercial bank that results from the conversion of a savings and loan association.

subsection.text: “Act” means the federal Bank Holding Company Act of 1956, as amended.

“Maryland bank holding company” means a company that is defined as a bank holding company under the Act and that conducted its principal banking business in Maryland on July 1, 1966, or on the date on which the company became a bank holding company under the Act, whichever occurred later.

“Out-of-state bank holding company” means a company that is defined as a bank holding company under the Act and that conducted its principal banking business in a jurisdiction of the United States other than Maryland on July 1, 1966, or on the date on which the company became a bank holding company under the Act, whichever occurred later.
“Savings accounts” has the meaning stated in § 10-101(k) of this article.
“Savings and loan association” means a corporation that is:

paragraph.text: Chartered under the laws of this State as a savings and loan association; and
Insured by the State of Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund Corporation.

section.text: The provisions of this subtitle which authorize an out-of-state bank holding company to acquire and hold certain institutions are only in effect through June 1, 1986. Any acquisition that was approved under this subtitle before June 1, 1986 remains subject to the terms and conditions that were in effect before that date, including the authorizations in § 5-1102(c) and (d) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: This subtitle sets forth the conditions under which an out-of-state bank holding company may acquire and hold:

paragraph.text: One or more savings and loan associations to be converted into one or more commercial banks; or
One or more newly-formed commercial banks that have acquired or acquire one or more savings and loan associations.

subsection.text: The acquisition of a commercial bank by an out-of-state bank holding company under this subtitle is authorized for purposes of § 3(d) of the Act.

Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an out-of-state bank holding company that has made an acquisition under this subtitle subsequently shall be permitted, directly or indirectly, to acquire and hold Maryland bank holding companies or constituent banks, as defined in Title 3, Subtitle 7 of this article, in this State as if the out-of-state bank holding company were a bank holding company the operations of whose banking subsidiaries are principally conducted in this State for purposes of § 3(d) of the Act. Any merger with or acquisition of a Maryland bank holding company by an out-of-state bank holding company, directly or indirectly, or any consolidation with, merger with or transfer of assets to a constituent bank by an out-of-state bank holding company, directly or indirectly, shall be governed by the procedural requirements of Subtitle 10 of this title.

Except for the procedural requirements of this section, an out-of-state bank holding company may acquire and hold Maryland bank holding companies or constituent banks in this State under subsection (c) of this section without regard to the restrictions found in Subtitle 10 of this title.

An out-of-state bank holding company may acquire one or more savings and loan associations and convert one or more of the acquired savings and loan associations into one or more commercial banks or one or more newly-formed commercial banks that have acquired or will acquire one or more savings and loan associations, if the out-of-state bank holding company and the entity to be acquired:

paragraph.text: File jointly an application and a plan of acquisition for approval with the Commissioner that contain the information the Commissioner may require;
Submit with the application:

subparagraph.text: The designation of a resident of this State as the applicant’s agent for the service of any paper, notice, or legal process on the applicant in connection with matters arising out of this subtitle; and
A filing fee of $5,000; and

paragraph.text: Receive approval of the acquisition from the Commissioner after the Commissioner has received:

subparagraph.text: Advice from the Director of the Division of Savings and Loan Associations and the Fund Director of the State of Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund Corporation; and
The concurrence of the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.

paragraph.text: The plan of acquisition under this section shall contain sufficient information to allow the Commissioner to consider the following:

subparagraph.text: The financial and managerial resources of the out-of-state bank holding company;
The future prospects and business plan for the successor commercial bank;
The financial history and future prospects of the out-of-state bank holding company;
The impact of the proposed acquisition on competition and concentration of financial resources in this State;

Initial capital investments, loan policy, investment policy, dividend policy, and general plan of business, including the amount and cost of consumer and business services to be offered in this State; and
The corporate and regulatory steps necessary to consummate the acquisition.

paragraph.text: An out-of-state bank holding company that has made an acquisition under this subtitle shall, within 30 days of adoption, submit to the Commissioner a copy of its most recently adopted federal Community Reinvestment Act statement.

Within 30 days of receipt, the holding company shall submit to the Commissioner a copy of the public portion of its most recent Community Reinvestment Act performance evaluation prepared by the federal regulatory agency that examines the holding company, together with a copy of any written response to the evaluation prepared by the holding company for its public Community Reinvestment Act file.

subparagraph.text: Upon request, the Commissioner shall make available to the public a copy of the documents submitted under this subsection.
The Commissioner may charge a reasonable fee to a person requesting a copy to help defray the costs of providing copies of the documents to the public.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, any person who knowingly submits false information to the Commissioner while complying with this section is guilty of a misdemeanor.
A person who violates this section is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000, or imprisonment for not more than 5 years, or both.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may not grant approval of an acquisition and conversion under this subsection unless the Commissioner finds:

paragraph.text: One or more of the savings and loan associations to be acquired:

subparagraph.text: Was placed into a conservatorship or receivership under Title 9, Subtitle 7 of this article before October 15, 1985, and continues to be under the control of a conservator or receiver at the time the plan of acquisition is filed; or

Before October 15, 1985, has been the subject of an executive order imposing limitations on withdrawals from savings accounts that are more restrictive than those set forth in Executive Order 01.01.1985.11 (May 21, 1985), as amended;
The aggregate total savings account liability of the association or associations to be acquired was at least $450,000,000 on June 1, 1985; or
The aggregate total savings account liability is less than $450,000,000 but greater than $250,000,000 on June 1, 1985, and the approval is:

sub-subparagraph.text: Reasonably required to protect the welfare of the general economy of this State and of the acquired association or associations;
Not detrimental to the public interest or to the acquired association or associations;
Consistent with the general need for banking services in the State; and
Concurred in by the Governor;

paragraph.text: Exigent circumstances exist such that the planned acquisition is necessary to maintain the viability or prevent the probable failure of one or more of the savings and loan associations to be acquired;
The out-of-state bank holding company has sufficient financial strength to assume its obligations under paragraph (5) of this subsection;
The application contains the unconditional undertaking of the out-of-state bank holding company to be bound by the provisions of § 5-1107 of this subtitle;
The commercial bank to be formed will be a member of the Federal Reserve System; and

That, upon the completion of any mergers, conversions, or acquisition to be made under the plan of acquisition, immediate access to savings accounts by account holders is provided subject to any terms and conditions governing those savings accounts.
Each merger, conversion, or acquisition to be made under the plan of acquisition:

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in this subtitle, shall comply with Title 3 of the Corporations and Associations Article;
Shall be approved by the board of directors of each commercial bank and savings and loan association; and
Subject to the provisions of paragraph (3) of this subsection, requires approval by a majority vote of the total number of votes entitled to be cast on the matter.

paragraph.text: As to each conversion, the savings and loan association to be converted shall file with the Commissioner a bank charter and otherwise comply with § 3-203 of this article.

Sufficient evidence of the approval required by paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection is a written consent signed by the shareholders or members having not less than a majority of the votes that would be entitled to be voted at a meeting at which all shareholders or members were present.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this section or any other law, the approval by the shareholders or members of a savings and loan association for which a receiver has been appointed under § 9-708 of this article of a merger, conversion, or acquisition involving that savings and loan association is not required if, after notice and a hearing, the circuit court administering the receivership determines that:

subparagraph.text: The savings and loan association is insolvent; or

The merger, conversion, or acquisition will not result in the shareholders or members of the association receiving property of a lesser value in their capacity as shareholders or members than they otherwise would upon a complete liquidation of the savings and loan association in receivership.

subsection.text: The provisions of Title 3, Subtitle 7 and Title 9, Subtitle 6 of this article do not apply to any consolidation, merger, transfer of assets, or conversion under this subtitle.

section.text: If the Commissioner deems it appropriate in order to consummate an acquisition under this subtitle, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: Convert the charter, form of ownership, or operating powers of a savings and loan association into the charter, form of ownership, or operating powers of a commercial bank;
Authorize the consolidation, merger, or transfer of assets of a savings and loan association into one or more savings and loan associations or commercial banks; and

Charter a new commercial bank or savings and loan association to acquire all or a substantial portion of the assets and liabilities of an existing savings and loan association, including all savings accounts liabilities and liabilities to the State.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (b), (c), (d), and (e) of this section, a commercial bank acquired under this subtitle may exercise all the powers of, and shall be subject only to those restrictions imposed on a commercial bank owned by a Maryland bank holding company under applicable State law.

A commercial bank that results from a conversion of a savings and loan association or acquires a savings and loan association may hold assets or conduct business activities, other than insurance assets and insurance activities, that result from the acquisition of a savings and loan association and that do not conform with applicable law, unless a different period is authorized by federal regulatory agencies:

paragraph.text: For a period of 5 years after the acquisition; and
If the Commissioner approves, for an additional period not exceeding 5 years.

subsection.text: A commercial bank that results from a conversion of a savings and loan association or acquires a savings and loan association may hold insurance assets or conduct insurance activities that result from the acquisition of a savings and loan association and that do not conform with applicable law, unless a different period is authorized by federal regulatory agencies, for a period of 2 years after the date of acquisition.

Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a commercial bank acquired under this subtitle may hold insurance assets or conduct insurance activities only to the extent permitted under applicable law to a Maryland commercial bank.

A commercial bank that results from the conversion of a savings and loan association or acquires a savings and loan association that is subject to the provisions of this section may not exercise any rights afforded to a Maryland bank, a Maryland bank holding company, or an out-of-state bank holding company under any Maryland law authorizing reciprocal interstate banking acquisitions until such time as national reciprocal interstate banking is authorized under State law.
Notwithstanding any other provisions of law to the contrary, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: Exercise any State regulatory approval that may be required to complete a plan of acquisition under this subtitle; and

Waive any procedural requirements, including publication and hearing procedures, if the Commissioner determines that prompt approval of the application protects the best interests of the depositors and creditors of the savings and loan association to be acquired under this subtitle and is in the public interest.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall give notice in the Maryland Register of the final action that has been taken on an application filed under this subtitle.

section.text: Upon and after the acquisition of each savings and loan association or commercial bank successor to a savings and loan association to be acquired under this subtitle, the out-of-state bank holding company and the acquired institution shall, unless otherwise determined in writing by the Fund Director to be in the best financial interest of the Fund:

paragraph.text: Defend, indemnify, and hold harmless the State of Maryland, its agencies, instrumentalities, officials, agents, and employees from all claims of:

subparagraph.text: Holders of savings accounts in that savings and loan association arising out of insurance of their accounts by the Maryland Savings-Share Insurance Corporation or the State of Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund Corporation; and

Parties to loan agreements, loan commitments, lines of credit, or letters of credit of that savings and loan association arising solely out of the failure of the commercial bank to honor within a reasonable period of time after its acquisition by the out-of-state bank holding company the terms of a legally binding written commitment entered into by that savings and loan association;

paragraph.text: Relinquish any right to and release the State of Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund Corporation from any obligation to return any part of the capital deposit required for membership in the Fund; and

Provide for repayment of any indebtedness incurred by an acquired savings and loan association to the former Maryland Savings-Share Insurance Corporation or the State of Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund Corporation.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the board of directors of a credit union.

paragraph.text: “Branch” means a credit union office at which shares or deposits are received, share drafts or checks are paid, or money is lent.
“Branch” includes a mobile branch or other special-purpose facility that performs a function of a branch.
“Branch” does not include an automated teller machine as defined in § 1-401(d) of this article.

subsection.text: “Credit union” means a cooperative, nonprofit financial institution organized under this title to conduct business in the State.
“Credit union service organization” means an entity formed to engage in activities that:

paragraph.text: Are incidental to the conduct of the business of a credit union;
Advance or facilitate the purposes of a credit union; and
Primarily serve a credit union and its members.
“Credit union share guaranty corporation” means a corporation engaged in the business of guaranteeing or insuring payment of a credit union share or deposit account.
“Credit union share guaranty corporation” includes the Credit Union Insurance Corporation established under Title 7 of this article.

subsection.text: “Deposit account” means a balance held by a credit union on which a contractual rate of interest may be paid as a debt owed by the credit union to the depositor.
“Fixed assets” include land, buildings, leasehold improvements, furniture, fixtures, and equipment used in the conduct of the regular business of a credit union.
“Member in good standing” means a member who:

paragraph.text: Owns at least one share in a credit union;
Is current on all credit obligations to the credit union; and
Has not caused the credit union a credit or deposit loss that is currently outstanding.

subsection.text: “Officer” means any officer that a Maryland corporation is required or permitted to have under § 2-412 of the Corporations and Associations Article.
“Official” means:

paragraph.text: A director;
A member of a credit committee; or
A member of a supervisory committee.

subsection.text: “Out-of-state credit union” means:

paragraph.text: A federal credit union with its main office in a state other than this State; or
A credit union chartered and primarily regulated by another state.

subsection.text: “Share” or “share account” means a balance held by a credit union on which a dividend may be paid and which confers membership and voting rights on the member.

section.text: Except as otherwise indicated in this title, Titles 3 through 5 of this article do not apply to credit unions.
Credit unions are subject to the supervision of the Commissioner.

A credit union incorporated under the laws of this State, including its income, net worth, and other funds are exempt from all taxes imposed by this State or by any of its political subdivisions to the same extent as federal credit unions are exempt.

A credit union may exercise all the rights, privileges, and incidental powers necessary or appropriate to exercise its specific powers and to accomplish the purposes for which the credit union is organized.
This title shall be construed liberally to effectuate its purpose.
This title may be cited as the Maryland Credit Union Act.

subsection.text: In this section, “organization” includes any trade, profession, club, union, religious congregation, society, association, fraternal group, or cooperative.
Seven or more adult individuals, each of whom is a resident of this State, may act as incorporators to form a credit union under this subtitle with one of the following field of membership types:

paragraph.text: Single common bond;
Multiple common bond; or
Community common bond.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the following provisions shall govern the field of membership types.
A single common bond credit union may serve one group of individuals all of whom as a common bond:

subparagraph.text: Belong to the same recognized organization;
Are employed by a single corporation or other person;
Are employed by a single corporation or other person with at least a 10% ownership interest in or by another single corporation or person;
Are employed by a single corporation or other person that is related to another person, such as by contract and possessing a strong dependency relationship; or
Are employed by or attend the same school.

paragraph.text: A multiple common bond credit union may serve one or more groups of individuals, as described in paragraph (2) of this subsection, as long as:

subparagraph.text: Within each group all individuals have a common bond of organization or occupation; and
Each group is within reasonable geographic proximity and has access to a branch of the credit union.

Subject to the provisions of subparagraphs (ii) and (iii) of this paragraph and subsection (d) of this section, a community credit union may serve a group of individuals, all members of which, as a common bond, live, work, worship, or attend school within a single or two or more contiguous well-defined local communities, neighborhoods, rural districts, or counties.

If the common bond is within a single well-defined local community, neighborhood, rural district, or county, the total population at the time of the formation of the credit union may not exceed 300,000.

If the common bond is within two or more contiguous well-defined local communities, neighborhoods, rural districts, or counties, the total population at the time of the formation of the credit union may not exceed 200,000.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (c)(4) of this section, any credit union, without regard to its field of membership type, may include in its field of membership, without regard to location, a community, neighborhood, rural district, or county if:

paragraph.text: The Commissioner determines that the community, neighborhood, rural district, or county is:

subparagraph.text: An “investment area” as defined in 12 U.S.C. § 4702(16) of the Community Development Banking and Financial Institutions Act of 1994; and
Underserved by other depository financial institutions based on data of the Commissioner, the federal credit union and banking regulatory agencies, or other data sources; and

paragraph.text: The credit union establishes and maintains an office or branch in the community, neighborhood, rural district, or county at which credit union services are available within 2 years after the inclusion of the community, neighborhood, rural district, or county in the field of membership of the credit union.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, only a group with fewer than 3,000 members, excluding individuals who are eligible under § 6-302(b)(4) or (5) of this subtitle, shall be eligible to be included in the membership of a multiple common bond credit union.
The numerical limitation in paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply with respect to a group:

subparagraph.text: That the Commissioner determines could not feasibly or reasonably establish a new single common bond credit union;
Transferred from another credit union in connection with:

sub-subparagraph.text: A merger or consolidation approved by the Commissioner based on safety and soundness concerns; or
A liquidation approved by the Commissioner; or

subparagraph.text: Transferred through the merger or consolidation of two credit unions, both of which served the group immediately before the merger or consolidation.

subsection.text: In this section, “immediate family relative” means:

paragraph.text: A spouse;
A child;
A sibling;
A parent;
A grandparent;
A grandchild;
A stepparent;
A stepchild;
A step-sibling; or
Any adopted relative.

subsection.text: A member of a credit union may be:

paragraph.text: An individual who shares with other members of the credit union one of the common bonds within the field of membership types approved by the Commissioner;
An employee of the credit union;
An entity that is composed primarily of individuals who are eligible for membership;
An individual living in the same residence and maintaining a single economic unit with an individual who is eligible for membership; and
An immediate family relative of an individual who is eligible for membership.

subsection.text: A person that is eligible for membership under subsection (b) of this section becomes a member when the person:

paragraph.text: Subscribes to and pays for at least one share; and
Meets all of the other requirements of the bylaws of the credit union.

subsection.text: Once an individual who is eligible for membership under subsection (b)(4) or (5) of this section becomes a member, then an immediate family relative of the member is eligible to become a member.
A member remains a member of a credit union until the member:

paragraph.text: Chooses to withdraw from the membership of the credit union; or
Is expelled by the board under § 6-319 of this subtitle.

Subject to the provisions of § 6-301(c) and (e) of this subtitle, a multiple common bond credit union may add to its field of membership a group of over 750 potential members, excluding individuals who are eligible for membership under § 6-302(b)(4) or (5) of this subtitle, if:

subparagraph.text: The members have approved the necessary amendment to the bylaws, as required under § 6-320(a) of this subtitle;
The credit union files with the Commissioner an application and any other documents that the Commissioner deems necessary to make a determination; and
The Commissioner determines that:

sub-subparagraph.text: The credit union has not engaged in any material unsafe or unsound practice during the 1-year period preceding the date of filing the application;
The credit union has adequate net worth;

The credit union has the administrative capability to serve the potential members of the group and the financial resources to meet the need for additional staff and assets to serve the potential members of the group;

Any potential harm that the expansion may have on any other credit union and its membership is clearly outweighed in the public interest by the probable beneficial effect of the expansion in meeting the convenience and needs of the potential members of the group;
Formation of a separate credit union by the group is not practicable and consistent with reasonable safety and soundness standards; and
The group is within reasonable geographic proximity to a branch of the credit union.

paragraph.text: Unless the Commissioner notifies the credit union that a different time period is necessary, within 60 days after the application is filed, the Commissioner shall notify the credit union of the determination on the application.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of § 6-301(c) and (e) of this subtitle, a multiple common bond credit union may add to its field of membership a group of 750 or less potential members, excluding individuals who are eligible under § 6-302(b)(4) or (5) of this subtitle, if:

paragraph.text: The board approves the addition of the group;
The credit union notifies the Commissioner in writing within 30 days after the board approves the addition of the group;
The requirements of subsection (a)(1)(iii) of this section are met; and
The addition of the group has not been disapproved by the Commissioner within 30 days of the notification required under item (2) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A credit union may convert to another field of membership type, as described in § 6–301 of this subtitle, if:

paragraph.text: The credit union:

subparagraph.text: Meets the common bond requirements of the proposed field of membership type; and
Files with the Commissioner an application and any other documents that the Commissioner deems necessary to make a determination on the application; and

paragraph.text: The Commissioner determines that approval:

subparagraph.text: Is in the best interest of the existing and proposed memberships;
Provides a means for better service to the existing membership;
Is in accordance with sound credit union practices; and
Does not expose the funds of the existing members to unnecessary risk.

subsection.text: Unless the Commissioner notifies the credit union that a different time period is necessary, within 120 days after the application is filed, the Commissioner shall notify the credit union of the determination on the application.

paragraph.text: No less than 30 days before the effective date of the conversion, the credit union shall give notice of the conversion to all groups of potential members of the credit union that will be removed from the field of membership as a result of the conversion.
On and after the effective date of the conversion, the credit union:

subparagraph.text: May not continue to serve groups within the field of membership of the credit union that no longer qualify for membership in the credit union as a result of the conversion; and
May continue to serve members of a group identified under item (i) of this paragraph who are members before the effective date of the conversion.

subsection.text: The incorporators shall sign and acknowledge three copies of articles of incorporation.
The articles of incorporation shall include:

paragraph.text: The name and residential address of each incorporator;
A statement that each incorporator is 18 years of age or older;
A statement that the incorporators are associating to form a credit union under this title;
The name of the credit union;
The field of membership type as described in § 6-301 of this subtitle;
The municipal area and county where the credit union is to be located;
The par value of the shares of the credit union;
The number of shares to which each incorporator subscribes;
The name and address in the State of the resident agent of the credit union for purposes of service of process in accordance with the Maryland General Corporation Law; and
The number of directors and the names and residential addresses of the individuals who will serve as directors on the board until their successors are elected and qualify.

subsection.text: The incorporators shall adopt bylaws for the credit union and shall sign and acknowledge two copies of them.
The bylaws of the credit union shall include:

paragraph.text: The name and purpose of the credit union;
Provisions for annual and special meetings of members and the manner of notification for and conduct of the meetings;
The number of members that constitute a quorum and provisions that relate to voting;
A detailed description of the field of membership;
The qualifications for membership;
The number of directors on the board and their powers and duties;
The powers and duties of its credit committee, if any, and supervisory committee;
The powers and duties of its officers;
The number of and qualifications for directors emeriti, if any;
The par value of its shares and the conditions for issuance, payment, transfer, and withdrawal;
The conditions on which deposits may be received and withdrawn; and
Provisions for determining and paying dividends on shares and interest on deposits.

subsection.text: The incorporators shall:

paragraph.text: File with the Commissioner for examination three copies of the articles of incorporation and two copies of the bylaws; and
Pay to the Commissioner a fee of $500.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall investigate and determine if:

paragraph.text: The articles and bylaws are framed in accordance with law and are reasonable;

The character, responsibility, and general fitness of the incorporators command confidence and warrant belief that the business of the proposed credit union will be conducted honestly and efficiently, in accordance with the intent of this title; and
Allowing the proposed credit union to engage in business:

subparagraph.text: Will promote public convenience and advantage; and
Is expedient and desirable.

subsection.text: After the investigation, the Commissioner may require any change in the articles of incorporation or bylaws that the Commissioner considers necessary.

paragraph.text: Unless the Commissioner notifies the applicant that a different time period is necessary, within 120 days after the articles and bylaws are filed, the Commissioner shall sign, date, and endorse each copy of the articles and bylaws as “approved” or “refused”.
If formation of the credit union is refused, the Commissioner shall notify the incorporators in writing of the reason for the refusal.
If formation of the credit union is approved, the Commissioner shall:

subparagraph.text: Return to the incorporators two of the endorsed copies of the articles and one of the endorsed copies of the bylaws; and
Keep one of the endorsed copies of the articles and the bylaws.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner approves the articles and bylaws, the incorporators shall file for record with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation one of the endorsed copies of the articles of incorporation.
When the articles of incorporation are filed for record in accordance with the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the credit union becomes a corporation.

When filing the articles of incorporation and bylaws with the Commissioner under § 6-307 of this subtitle, the incorporators shall file with the Commissioner an initial application on a form that the Commissioner requires.
The initial application shall include:

paragraph.text: The field of membership type requested;
A detailed description of the field of membership;
A mission statement;
A detailed business plan that includes the items that the Commissioner reasonably requires; and
Any other information that the Commissioner reasonably requires.

In connection with an initial application and at any other time the Commissioner requests, each incorporator and director shall provide fingerprints for use by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to conduct criminal history records checks.

Any incorporator or director required by this subsection to provide fingerprints shall pay any processing or other fee required by the Federal Bureau of Investigation or the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
The fingerprinting and criminal history records check requirements shall apply to any other official or officer of the credit union as requested by the Commissioner.

section.text: In addition to the powers set forth elsewhere in this title, a credit union may:

paragraph.text: Receive the shares and deposits of its members;
Lend money to its members;
Invest funds as provided in this title; and
Undertake other activities that:

subparagraph.text: Are consistent with this title;
Relate to its purposes; and
Are authorized by its bylaws.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of the laws or regulations of the State, on approval of the Commissioner, a credit union may engage in any additional activity, service, or other practice in which, under federal law or regulation, federal credit unions may engage.
The Commissioner may grant an approval under this section only if:

paragraph.text: The Commissioner determines that approval:

subparagraph.text: Reasonably is required to protect the welfare of the general economy of the State and of credit unions; or
Is not detrimental to the public interest or to credit unions; and

paragraph.text: The approval imposes the same conditions that federal law or regulation requires or permits as to federal credit unions.

subsection.text: Without being required to take any action to perfect a lien, a credit union has a lien and a right to a setoff on the shares and deposits of a member in any individual, multiple party, or other type of account, including any dividends or interest payable on those shares or deposits, to the extent of any delinquency or default of the member on:

paragraph.text: Any outstanding loan, whether or not matured, on which the member is liable to the credit union as maker, comaker, surety, or endorser; and
Any dues, charges, fees, fines, or other amount payable by the member.

subsection.text: If a member resigns or is expelled, the credit union may cancel that member’s shares and apply their withdrawal value against any amount owed to the credit union by the member.
A credit union may allow a withdrawal of a member’s shares or deposits without affecting the credit union’s lien or right to a setoff.
A credit union may refuse to allow a withdrawal of a member’s shares or deposits to the extent of any delinquency or default of the member to the credit union.

paragraph.text: The annual meeting of the members shall be held as provided by the bylaws and at the time and place that the board determines.
Special meetings of members shall be held:

subparagraph.text: On order of the directors or the supervisory committee; or
At the request of 10 percent of the members.

paragraph.text: Notice of each meeting shall be given as the bylaws provide.
Each member in good standing has one vote, notwithstanding the number of shares that the member holds.
A member may not vote by proxy. However, a member that is not an individual may be represented by an individual authorized in writing by the member to represent it.
A member may not vote or hold office if the member is less than 18 years of age.
At any meeting of the members, the members may:

subparagraph.text: Decide any question of interest to the credit union;

Except for any instance where, in the judgment of the board, it would result in damage to the credit union’s financial soundness or would otherwise force the board to abrogate their fiduciary responsibility, overrule any decision of the board; and
Amend the bylaws or articles of incorporation as provided in § 6-320 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: At the annual meeting of the members, the members shall elect directors, unless they are elected as provided in § 6-329 of this subtitle or as provided in the bylaws for mail balloting.

subsection.text: The provisions of this section do not apply to:

paragraph.text: An action authorized under § 6-329 or § 6-321 of this subtitle;
A voluntary dissolution under § 6-804 of this title; or
An authorization of compensation under § 6-331 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The board of a credit union:

paragraph.text: May authorize by resolution any question, proposal, or other matter requiring membership approval to be voted on by mail ballot; and
Shall establish a sequence of dates by which the voting procedures are initiated and completed.

subsection.text: The secretary of the credit union shall mail to each member in good standing who is eligible to vote:

paragraph.text: A printed ballot;
An explanation of the question, proposal, or other matter to be voted on; and
A postage pre-paid and pre-addressed return envelope.

subsection.text: Unless otherwise provided in this title, the printed ballot shall be mailed to each member in good standing who is eligible to vote, not more than 30 days nor less than 7 days before the date set by the board for the filing of the mail ballot.

paragraph.text: The question, proposal, or other matter is adopted only if approved by a majority of the ballots timely received from the members eligible to vote and in good standing and voting.
The credit union shall report the results of the mail ballot to the members.

subsection.text: Subject to the applicable provisions of the bylaws, the board may expel any member of the credit union who:

paragraph.text: Defaults on the payment of any monetary obligation to the credit union;
Is convicted of a criminal offense involving dishonesty or breach of trust;
Neglects or refuses to comply with the provisions of this title or of the bylaws of the credit union;
Habitually neglects to pay debts or becomes insolvent or bankrupt; or
Subject to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, violates a written expulsion policy adopted by the board.
The board shall post conspicuously at each office of the credit union a notice of any expulsion policy adopted by the board.
A person expelled by the board may request a reconsideration of the expulsion.
The board may amend the articles of incorporation only if the members approve the amendment.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the board may amend the bylaws without approval of the members.
The board may amend the bylaws only with the approval of the members for any amendment that addresses one of the following subjects:

sub-subparagraph.text: The manner or method by which a meeting of the members can be convened;
Quorum requirements for a meeting of the members;
The voting rights of members;
Except as provided in § 6-303(b) of this subtitle, any change in the field of membership;
Requirements for the number, classifications, qualifications, and term of office for directors;
Procedures for removing directors;
Procedures for filling vacancies on the board; and
Any other issue as determined by the Commissioner.

subsection.text: At any meeting of the members, the members may amend the articles of incorporation or, may approve an amendment to the bylaws as provided in subsection (a)(2)(ii) of this section, if:

paragraph.text: The notice of the meeting specifies the amendment to be considered; and
Two-thirds of the members present vote for the amendment.
An amendment to the articles of incorporation does not become effective until:

subparagraph.text: The amendment is approved by the Commissioner in writing no later than 60 days after the date of submission of the proposed amendment, unless the Commissioner and the credit union agree to a longer period of time; and
A copy of the amendment certified by the Commissioner is filed with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

paragraph.text: Whether approved only by the board or by the members as required under subsection (a)(2)(ii) of this section, an amendment to the bylaws does not become effective until the amendment is approved by the Commissioner in writing no later than 60 days after the date of submission of the proposed amendment, unless the Commissioner and the credit union agree to a longer period of time.

subsection.text: The action of the Commissioner on the proposed amendment to the articles of incorporation or the bylaws under subsection (c)(1)(i) or (2) of this section shall be based on a finding as to whether or not the proposed amendment:

paragraph.text: Is in the best interest of the membership;
Provides means for better service to the membership;
Is in accord with sound credit union practices; and
Exposes the members’ funds to unnecessary risk.

subsection.text: The board shall report an amendment to the members of the credit union no later than the next meeting of the members after the Commissioner approves the amendment.
The board:

paragraph.text: By resolution may authorize an amendment to the bylaws or articles of incorporation to be voted on by mail ballot; and
Shall establish a sequence of dates by which the voting procedures are initiated and completed.

subsection.text: The secretary of the credit union shall mail to each member in good standing:

paragraph.text: A printed ballot;
A copy of any old bylaw or article of incorporation affected by the proposed amendment; and
A copy of the proposed bylaw or article of incorporation.
The amendment is adopted only if approved by two-thirds of the mail ballots timely received from the members in good standing and voting.
The credit union shall report the results of the mail ballot to the credit union members.

section.text: The board shall have the authority and responsibility for the business affairs, funds, and records of a credit union.

subsection.text: Each credit union shall have at least five directors.
Each director:

paragraph.text: Shall be a member of the credit union;
Shall be bonded;
May not have:
