subparagraph.text: Defaulted on the payment of any monetary obligation to the credit union;
Been convicted of any criminal offense involving dishonesty or breach of trust;
Habitually neglected to pay debts;
Become insolvent or bankrupt; or
Been removed by any state or federal regulatory agency from office as an officer, official, or employee of a financial institution; and

paragraph.text: Shall comply with any other qualifications set forth in the credit union bylaws.

subsection.text: A director holds office for the term that the bylaws provide, which may not exceed 3 years, and until a successor is elected and qualifies.
Each director shall take an oath that the director:

paragraph.text: Will diligently and honestly perform the duties as director in administering the credit union’s affairs;
Will remain responsible for the performance of the duties of the director even if the director delegates the performance of the duties; and
Will not knowingly or willfully permit the violation of an applicable law or regulation.

subsection.text: The chairman and, if any, vice chairman of the board shall be elected by and from the directors.
The office of a director becomes vacant if the director:

paragraph.text: Dies;
Resigns; or
Is removed.

subsection.text: A director may be removed from office:

paragraph.text: By the board, in accordance with the bylaws, if the director:

subparagraph.text: Does not possess or maintain the qualifications required to serve on the board; or
Is absent from three consecutive regular meetings of the board unless excused; or

paragraph.text: By the members.
Unless the bylaws provide otherwise, the remaining directors by majority vote shall fill a vacancy.
A director elected by the board to fill a vacancy holds office as the bylaws provide.

subsection.text: If the bylaws provide, a director emeritus may advise and consult with the board and aid the board in carrying out the board’s duties and responsibilities.
The bylaws shall provide for:

paragraph.text: The number of directors emeriti; and
The qualifications for a director emeritus.

subsection.text: A director emeritus:

paragraph.text: Shall be a member of the credit union; and
May not be an officer or an official.

subsection.text: A director emeritus may not:

paragraph.text: Participate in any board or committee deliberations;
Make motions; or
Vote on any matter before the board.

subsection.text: In addition to any power or duty provided for by law, the board shall:

paragraph.text: Act on each application for membership;
Approve the amount of any blanket fidelity bond and any appropriate insurance or surety bond;
Limit the number of shares or deposits that a member or depositor may hold;
Limit the amount that the credit union may lend to any one member and establish the interest rate on all loans;
Determine the interest rate on deposits and the manner of calculation;

In the absence of a credit committee, appoint one or more loan officers and delegate to those officers the power to approve or disapprove loans and lines of credit in accordance with written policies established by the board;
In the absence of a credit committee and upon written request of a member, review a loan application denied by a loan officer or establish a subcommittee of the board for this purpose;
Fill any vacancy on the supervisory committee or, if any, a credit committee;
Manage the investment of credit union funds in accordance with written investment policies established by the board;
Set the amount of compensation for the president;
Appoint standing or special committees, as necessary, to carry on the business of the credit union and prescribe conditions and limitations for any committee that the board appoints;
Approve an annual operating budget for the credit union;
Establish and adopt written policies necessary to implement the powers and duties of the credit union, including policies on:

subparagraph.text: Loans and lending;
Investments;
Employment and personnel;
Funds management;
Collections;
Charge offs; and
Expulsion of members;

paragraph.text: Make adequate provision for:

subparagraph.text: Investment losses;
The statutory reserve account;
Any special reserve account; and
The allowance for a loan and lease loss account;

paragraph.text: Determine the amount, if any, that may be assessed for late fees or other charges;
Delegate to the officers, employees, or committees duties as the board may deem appropriate;
Establish and maintain a system of internal controls consistent with safety and soundness and generally accepted accounting principles; and

Except for any instance where, in the judgment of the board, it would result in damage to the credit union’s financial soundness or would otherwise force the board to abrogate their fiduciary responsibility, perform every other duty that the members require.
Subject to the provisions of paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, the board may suspend a member of the supervisory committee.
The suspension:

subparagraph.text: Shall be by a two-thirds vote of the board; and
Takes effect immediately and remains in effect until the board convenes a meeting of the members to vote on the suspension.

paragraph.text: Immediately after the board votes to suspend a member of the supervisory committee, the board shall:

subparagraph.text: Call a meeting of the members, to be held no later than 15 days after the date of the suspension, for the purpose of voting on the suspension; and
Notify the Commissioner in writing about the suspension.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, the directors may be elected exclusively by mail ballot or electronically in accordance with regulations adopted by the Commissioner, if:

paragraph.text: The board of the credit union, by resolution posted conspicuously at the principal office of the credit union at least 90 days before the annual meeting of the members of the credit union, authorizes the election of directors exclusively by mail ballot or electronically; or

subparagraph.text: The bylaws provide for the election of directors exclusively by mail ballot or electronically; and
Notice of the election and the annual meeting is posted conspicuously at the principal office of the credit union at least 90 days before the date of the annual meeting.

paragraph.text: At least 75 days before the annual meeting, the board of the credit union shall appoint a nominating committee of at least three members.

The nominating committee shall nominate at least one member for each vacancy on the board, after determining that a proposed nominee agrees to permit the nomination and, if elected, to accept the office.
The nominating committee shall file its nominations with the secretary of the credit union at least 60 days before the annual meeting.
The secretary shall post these nominations conspicuously at the principal office of the credit union at least 55 days before the annual meeting.

subparagraph.text: The lesser of 1 percent or 500 of the members in good standing, but in any case no less than 20, may nominate candidates for directorships by signing a petition.
Each page of the petition shall include:

sub-subparagraph.text: The name of the credit union; and
The name of the nominee.

subparagraph.text: Each petition shall contain:

sub-subparagraph.text: The printed or typed names, signatures, date, and account numbers of those members in good standing signing the petition; and
A certificate by each nominee that the nominee agrees to permit the nomination and, if elected, to accept the office.

subparagraph.text: The nominating committee shall determine the validity of any petition.

paragraph.text: Petitioners shall file their nomination with the secretary of the credit union at least 55 days before the annual meeting.
The secretary shall post these nominations conspicuously at the principal office of the credit union at least 20 days before the annual meeting.
When only one member is nominated for a position to be filled, the chairman may:

subparagraph.text: Take a voice vote; or
Declare the nominee elected by general consent or acclamation at the annual meeting.

paragraph.text: If the nominations of the nominating committee and any petitioners provide more than one nominee for each directorship to be filled, the secretary:

subparagraph.text: For an election of directors conducted by mail ballot, shall mail to each member in good standing, at least 20 days before the annual meeting:

sub-subparagraph.text: A printed ballot, clearly identified as a ballot, on which appears the name of each nominee, in alphabetical order, and on which, in the form that the board approves, may appear after a nominee’s name:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: A brief statement of the nominee’s qualifications and biographical information; and
If applicable, a notation that the nominee is the incumbent;

sub-subparagraph.text: A postage prepaid and preaddressed envelope clearly marked with instructions to place the completed ballot and the identification form in the envelope and seal the envelope; and
An identification form to be completed to include the name, address, signature, and credit union account number of the voter; and

subparagraph.text: For an election of directors conducted electronically, shall provide the information and identification form required under item (i) of this paragraph as provided in regulations adopted by the Commissioner.

paragraph.text: One form may be printed or provided electronically that represents a combined ballot and identification form.

subsection.text: The board shall appoint the tellers of the election.
The tellers of an election may not count a ballot unless it is:

paragraph.text: Mailed or electronically submitted to the tellers; and
Received by the tellers not later than midnight of the 7th day before the date of the annual meeting.

subsection.text: The tellers of the election shall:

paragraph.text: Verify or cause to be verified the name of each voter and the credit union account number of the voter as it appears on the identification form;
Authenticate any questionable or challenged identification form;
Keep the verified identification form and ballot for safekeeping pending the count of the vote;
Keep separate any questionable or challenged identification form and ballot until the authentication, verification, or challenge is resolved;
Determine that each eligible voter does not vote more than once and is a member in good standing; and
After the time set in subsection (f)(2) of this section, tally the votes and report the results to the board.

subsection.text: The board shall report the results of the election at the annual meeting of the members.
The Commissioner shall establish by regulation procedures for conducting an election of directors electronically, including procedures for:

paragraph.text: Providing notice of the election to each member in good standing;
Providing the information and identification form specified in subsection (d)(2)(i)1 of this section;
Providing instructions on how to access and use the electronic election system; and
Allowing a member to opt out of using the electronic election system and vote by mail ballot.

subsection.text: Within 15 days after the annual meeting of the members and after the directors-elect have qualified, the board shall meet and elect the officers of the credit union.
Unless the bylaws provide otherwise:

paragraph.text: Each officer serves for a term of 1 year and until a successor is elected and qualifies; and
The president shall be the chief executive officer who shall be responsible for the day to day operations of the credit union.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of an enforceable employment contract, if any, the board may remove an officer at any time.
In this section, “compensation” means anything of value given to an official that is:

paragraph.text: In exchange for services performed as an official; and
Reportable as income to the Internal Revenue Service or the Comptroller of the State.

subsection.text: Each official is entitled to the compensation that:

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of subsection (c) of this section, the members authorize; and
Except as provided in subsection (d)(2) of this section, is approved by the Commissioner.
All compensation to be paid under subsection (b) of this section shall be authorized by a vote of the members at the annual meeting of the membership in accordance with § 6-317 of this subtitle.

Written disclosure of the proposed compensation and each official’s expenses shall be made to all members in good standing not less than 30 days and not more than 90 days before the annual meeting of members.
The written disclosure required under paragraph (2) of this subsection shall contain at least the following information:

subparagraph.text: The proposed dollar amount of compensation that will be paid to each official on a per meeting or other applicable basis;
The aggregate dollar amount of compensation paid to all officials for the 12 months immediately preceding the date of the notice of the annual meeting of members;

sub-subparagraph.text: A reasonable estimate of the aggregate dollar amount of compensation to be paid to all officials for the following 12 month period assuming:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: That the proposed compensation is approved; and
The same number of meetings as were held during the 12 months immediately preceding the date of the notice of the annual meeting of members; or

sub-subparagraph.text: A statement that the compensation to be paid to all officials will remain the same as it was during the 12 months immediately preceding the date of the notice of the annual meeting of members; and

subparagraph.text: The aggregate dollar amount of all officials’ expenses, excluding compensation, for the 12 months immediately preceding the date of the notice of the annual meeting of members.
The written disclosure shall be conspicuously set apart from other information provided to the members.
The written disclosure may be included in:

sub-subparagraph.text: The notice of the annual meeting of the members;
A separate mailing;
A periodic statement of account; or
A periodic publication of the credit union.

paragraph.text: All requests for the Commissioner’s approval under subsection (b) of this section shall:

subparagraph.text: Be made in writing; and
Contain a certification by the president of the credit union that the compensation has been authorized by the membership in accordance with subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner’s approval is not required if the credit union:

subparagraph.text: Was rated “1” or “2” as of the last examination conducted by the Commissioner; and
Has a positive net income as of the end of the previous calendar year.

subsection.text: A board may call a special meeting of the members to act on a report or recommendation of the supervisory committee that concerns the suspension from office of a member of the credit committee, a director, or an officer.
The notice of the special meeting shall be given within 7 days after the board receives the report or recommendation.
The board shall prepare a plan for educating each official as to the duties and responsibilities that accompany the official’s position.
The education plan may include requiring an official to:

paragraph.text: Read materials;
Attend seminars, conferences, or workshops; or
Review films or tapes.

subsection.text: The preparation of and compliance with an education plan developed under this section may not be construed to limit the civil or criminal liability of an official arising from an act or omission by the official in the performance of any duty or responsibility of the official.
Each credit union shall have a supervisory committee.
The board shall appoint the members of the supervisory committee at:

paragraph.text: The first meeting of the board following the annual meeting of the members; and
Any time there is a vacancy.
Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, the board shall determine the number of members on the supervisory committee.
The supervisory committee shall have at least three and not more than seven members.
Each member of the supervisory committee shall be appointed from among the members of the credit union.
Not more than one member of the supervisory committee may be a director.
An officer of the credit union, a member of the credit committee, or an employee of the credit union may not be a member of the supervisory committee.
At least one member of the supervisory committee shall have experience in:

subparagraph.text: Accounting;
Auditing; or
General business.

paragraph.text: Each member of the supervisory committee:

subparagraph.text: Shall be bonded;
May not have been convicted of any criminal offense involving dishonesty or breach of trust;
May not have habitually neglected to pay any debts;
May not become insolvent or bankrupt while serving on the supervisory committee; and
May not have been removed by the Commissioner or any state or federal regulatory agency as an officer, official, or employee of a financial institution.

subsection.text: The members of the supervisory committee shall elect the chairman of the supervisory committee:

paragraph.text: At the beginning of each term of appointment to the committee; and
At any time there is a vacancy and the board is notified.

subsection.text: A member of the supervisory committee serves for 1 year and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
Each member of the supervisory committee shall take an oath to perform faithfully the duties of the office.

paragraph.text: The board shall appropriate funds:

subparagraph.text: For an audit conducted by an outside auditor; and
If required, for an internal auditing function.

paragraph.text: The supervisory committee has the sole authority to engage or terminate outside and internal auditors.

subsection.text: The supervisory committee is responsible for ensuring that the officials and officers:

paragraph.text: Meet required financial reporting objectives; and
Establish practices and procedures sufficient to safeguard members’ assets.

subsection.text: To meet its responsibilities, the supervisory committee shall determine whether:

paragraph.text: Internal controls are:

subparagraph.text: Established and effectively maintained to achieve the credit union’s financial reporting objectives; and
Sufficient to satisfy the requirements of the supervisory committee audit, verification of members’ accounts, and the supervisory committee’s additional responsibilities;

paragraph.text: The credit union’s accounting records and financial reports are promptly prepared and accurately reflect operations and results;
The relevant plans, policies, and control procedures established by the board are properly administered; and
The board’s plans, policies, and control procedures are sufficient to safeguard against error, carelessness, conflict of interest, self-dealing, and fraud.
The supervisory committee shall submit:

subparagraph.text: A report on the annual audit to the board; and
A summary of the report on the annual audit to the members at the annual meeting of the members.

paragraph.text: The supervisory committee shall conduct or cause to be conducted and shall submit to the board, supplementary audits as the supervisory committee deems necessary.
The supervisory committee shall submit written reports periodically to the board addressing activities since the last report.
The supervisory committee audit of a credit union shall occur at least once each calendar year and shall cover the period elapsed since the last audit period.
The supervisory committee annual audit shall meet the following minimum guidelines:

subparagraph.text: A credit union with assets over $250,000,000 shall have an opinion audit of the credit union’s financial statements performed by an independent licensed certified public accountant; and
A credit union with assets of less than $250,000,000 may satisfy the audit requirements by:

sub-subparagraph.text: An opinion audit of the credit union’s financial statements performed by an independent licensed certified public accountant;

In accordance with the provisions of paragraph (3) of this subsection, an agreed upon procedures engagement performed by a qualified person with appropriate knowledge of auditing concepts and credit union procedures; or
An audit performed by the supervisory committee or the credit union’s internal auditors.

paragraph.text: The following minimum procedures shall be satisfied under paragraphs (2)(ii)2 and (2)(ii)3 of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: Determine that the reserve fund is sufficient in accordance with § 6-703 of this title;
Determine that the credit union meets minimum net worth requirements in accordance with § 6-702 of this title;
Review and test the bank statement reconciliations by testing for mathematical accuracy and ensuring that reconciling items are reasonable and clear promptly;
Perform an unannounced cash count at some time during the period covered by the audit and ensure that the amount of cash counted agrees to the general ledger;
Review a sufficient number of current and delinquent loans to determine whether or not they are in accordance with the credit union’s underwriting policies and procedures as established by the board;
Determine that the trial balance listing of loans agrees with the general ledger;
Determine that the allowance for the loan and lease loss account meets the minimum standards required under § 6-704 of this title;
Determine that all loans that are delinquent 60 days or more are reported to the board monthly;
Determine that the investment subsidiary or list of investments agrees with the general ledger by performing the following procedures:

sub-subparagraph.text: Compare the balance of investments and accrued interest receivable from the subsidiary ledger to the general ledger;
Choose a sample of investments and compare the market value per the subsidiary ledger to an outside source;
Test the accrued interest and compare it to the subsidiary ledger;

Test a sample of investment purchases or sales during the audit period for proper authorization to make sure that the accounting treatment is correct, compare the terms of the transactions to a broker advice, and make sure that the investment is in accordance with board policy; and
Confirm all investments with any depository institution, broker, or third party safekeeping agent, or inspect the original certificate, if it is in the possession of the credit union;

subparagraph.text: Determine that the trial balance listing of shares and deposits agrees with the general ledger;
Perform a minimum of 20 share and deposit dividend and interest calculations paid during the audit period;
Obtain a list of all overdrawn share and deposit accounts and determine that management is attempting to collect these items;
Obtain a listing of other asset and other liability accounts, make a selection of five of these accounts including any suspense or clearing accounts, and perform the following procedures:

sub-subparagraph.text: Obtain reconciliations of the selected accounts and compare the balance to the general ledger;
Test the mathematical accuracy of the reconciliation; and
Determine whether any reconciling items have been outstanding for more than 30 days;

subparagraph.text: Perform a minimum of 20 loan interest calculations collected during the audit period;

Review the minutes of the board meetings to ensure that they document relevant decisions, including decisions about charged off loans, interest rate changes, policy changes, interest and dividend rates, personnel issues, and the annual budget; and
Other auditing procedures as are deemed necessary by the board, the Commissioner, or the supervisory committee.

paragraph.text: At least once every 2 years the supervisory committee or its designee shall verify the accounts of the members in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection.
The verification shall be performed using one of the following methods:

subparagraph.text: A 100% verification of the share and loan accounts of all members;
A statistical sampling of member share and loan accounts done in connection with an opinion audit of the financial statements performed by a licensed certified public accountant; or
A statistical sampling method that provides a random selection that is expected to be representative of the membership.

paragraph.text: A credit union with assets in excess of $250,000,000 shall have an internal audit function in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection.
The supervisory committee shall:

subparagraph.text: Hire one or more internal auditors to assist the supervisory committee in the performance of the audit duties of the supervisory committee;
Adopt and execute an annual internal audit plan that adheres to board policies and includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: An evaluation of internal controls; and
Operational procedures; and

subparagraph.text: Direct the duties of the internal auditor.

subsection.text: Any agreement between the supervisory committee and an outside auditor shall be documented by an engagement letter that specifies the terms, conditions, and objectives of the arrangement.

paragraph.text: All work performed by the supervisory committee, outside auditors, or internal auditors shall be documented by appropriate work papers.
The Commissioner shall have access to the work papers for a period of up to 3 years after the completion of the audit procedure.
At any time, by a unanimous vote, the supervisory committee may suspend a director, an officer, or a member of the credit committee for cause.

subparagraph.text: Subject to the provisions of subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the suspension will take effect immediately and stay in force until the board convenes a special meeting of the members to act on the suspension.
The meeting of the members shall take place no later than 15 days from the date of the vote to suspend, for the purpose of voting on the suspension.

paragraph.text: The supervisory committee shall notify the Commissioner in writing immediately at the time of the suspension of the director, officer, or member of the credit committee.

subsection.text: The supervisory committee shall send promptly to the Commissioner a copy of the annual audit and all recommendations, charges, and significant findings that the supervisory committee presents to the board.
In this section, “examiner” means:

paragraph.text: The Commissioner; and
An individual whom the Commissioner designates as examiner.

subsection.text: An examiner shall visit each credit union and examine its business:

paragraph.text: At least once during each calendar year, unless the Commissioner determines that, during a calendar year, an examination is unnecessary, in which event an examination shall occur no less frequently than once every 18 months;
When requested by the board or supervisory committee of the credit union; and
At any other time that the Commissioner considers necessary.

subsection.text: On or before March 31 of each year, each credit union shall report to the Commissioner on the business of the credit union during the preceding calendar year.
The Commissioner may require any other reports from a credit union that the Commissioner considers necessary.
Each report made under this section shall be:

paragraph.text: On the form that the Commissioner provides; and
Signed and acknowledged by:

subparagraph.text: A majority of the members of the supervisory committee; and
The president, vice-president, secretary, or treasurer of the credit union.

subsection.text: If a credit union fails to make any report as required by this title, the credit union shall pay to the Commissioner $50 for each day that the report is overdue.

If the Commissioner finds that the supervisory committee of a credit union is not performing its duties properly, the Commissioner may require the credit union to have a certified public accountant audit the credit union for any period of time that the Commissioner considers necessary.
The audit required under subsection (a) of this section shall be made at the expense of the credit union.
The board may call a meeting of the members of the credit union to act on any practice of the credit union that the supervisory committee considers unsafe or unauthorized.
The board shall give the Commissioner advance notice of a meeting of the members that is called under subsection (a) of this section.

section.text: In order to carry out the purposes of this title, the Commissioner may enter into cooperative and information sharing agreements with any other credit union supervisory agency.

As to each interest bearing or share account of each member or depositor in a credit union, the credit union shall generally make available to any member or depositor with an existing account, in addition to actually giving to the member or depositor, on the opening of the interest bearing or share account and, later, on demand of the member or depositor the following written notice:

“Under Maryland law, all funds remaining in this interest bearing or share account become the property of this State after the account has been inactive for 3 years and notice is sent to the member or depositor at that member’s or depositor’s last known address. This account will be considered inactive if the member or depositor has not: (1) increased or decreased the amount in the account; (2) presented the passbook or other similar evidence of the account for the crediting of interest or dividends; (3) written to this credit union about the account; (4) engaged in any credit, share, or other deposit transaction with the credit union; or (5) otherwise indicated an interest in the account as evidenced by a memorandum on file with this credit union.”

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the board may declare and pay dividends from its available net earnings or undivided earnings at the close of any accounting period after providing for accrued expenses and interest.
Dividends paid or accrued are to be treated as an expense.

subsection.text: The board shall set the dividend rate and any terms and conditions regarding the dividend.
A credit union may not declare a dividend:

paragraph.text: Unless the required amount of earnings has been credited to the reserve fund of the credit union; or
If the known losses at the close of a fiscal year would exceed the sum of the balances of the reserve fund, surplus, and undivided earnings after payment of the dividend.

subsection.text: Any share drafts or checks provided directly or indirectly by a credit union for use in connection with a personal account shall have the numerical month and year in which the account was opened printed on the face of the drafts or checks, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section.
The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply under the following conditions:

paragraph.text: If an individual personal account is closed at a particular credit union and a joint personal account is opened at the same credit union that includes one of the customers who previously had the individual personal account, then the numerical month and year printed on the face of the share drafts or checks shall be the numerical month and year in which the individual personal account was established.

If a joint personal account is closed at a particular credit union and an individual personal account is opened at the same credit union by one of the customers who previously was included under the joint account, then the numerical month and year printed on the face of the share drafts or checks shall be the numerical month and year in which the joint account was established.

If a customer with an individual personal account or with a joint personal account opens an additional account at the same credit union, then the numerical month and year printed on the face of the share drafts or checks shall be the numerical month and year in which the initial account was established.

In the case of a personal account that is closed and a new personal account opened simultaneously on the advice of the credit union, the share drafts or checks for the new account shall have the numerical month and year in which the closed account was originally opened printed on the face of the share drafts or checks.
If the closed account was opened prior to July 1, 1987, a date is not required to be printed on the share drafts or checks.

subsection.text: A share draft or check provided on the opening of a personal account for use by the customer until printed share drafts or checks have been prepared is not required to have the numerical month and year in which the account was opened printed on the face of the share draft or check.

paragraph.text: The credit union and the share draft or check printer may not be held liable for unintentional errors in the month and year printed on the face of the share draft or check.

The customer may not be charged for the reprinting of the share drafts or checks when the share drafts or checks are reprinted due to error in the month and year printed on the face of the share draft or check.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of this subtitle, a credit union may make loans and extend lines of credit to its members in accordance with written policies established by the board.

Notwithstanding subsection (e) of this section, § 6-606(d) of this subtitle, and § 12-913.1 of the Commercial Law Article, on or after October 1, 1994, a revolving credit plan and extensions of credit under a revolving credit plan offered and extended by a credit union to a member are made under and are subject to Title 12, Subtitle 9 of the Commercial Law Article.

Notwithstanding subsection (e) of this section, § 6-606(d) of this subtitle, and § 12-1013.1 of the Commercial Law Article, on or after October 1, 1994, a closed end loan made by a credit union to a member is made under and is subject to Title 12, Subtitle 10 of the Commercial Law Article.

Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section and § 6-606(d) of this subtitle, and except as otherwise provided under the express terms of the agreement, note, or other evidence of an extension of credit or loan, the provisions of Title 12, Subtitle 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, or 10 of the Commercial Law Article do not apply to an extension of credit or loan made by a credit union before October 1, 1994.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to an extension of credit or loan made by a credit union on or after October 1, 1994.
Except as otherwise expressly provided in this title, a credit union may not charge interest on any loan to a member at a rate of more than 1.5% a month on the unpaid balance.

Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1) of this subsection, a credit union may charge interest on a loan to a member made on or after July 1, 1982, at 2% a month on the unpaid balance provided, with respect to the loan, that:

subparagraph.text: If the loan is a renewal or refinancing of a loan made prior to July 1, 1982, the lender complies with § 12-116 of the Commercial Law Article;
If the loan includes a provision for a rate of interest which may be adjusted by the lender during the term of the loan, the lender complies with § 12-118 of the Commercial Law Article;

Upon the borrower’s default, if the loan is secured by personal property, the lender complies with § 12-115 of the Commercial Law Article concerning repossession and redemption of the goods securing the loan;
If the loan is for the purchase of consumer goods, the loan contract complies with § 12-117 of the Commercial Law Article; and
The loan does not include a balloon payment, unless payment in full is due on demand or in 1 year or less.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any provision of Title 12 of the Commercial Law Article, if the credit agreement provides, a credit union may make loans or extend credit to its members incorporating the same terms and conditions as a federal credit union is permitted under federal law and regulations relating to:

paragraph.text: Over the limit fees for credit cards; and
Fees for ancillary and administrative services requested by the member, including:

subparagraph.text: Researching account records;
Providing duplicate statements and other documents; and
Expedited issuance of a duplicate or original credit card or device.

subsection.text: If the bylaws so provide, a credit union may have a credit committee.
The board shall appoint the members of the credit committee.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, the board shall determine the number of members on the credit committee.
The credit committee shall have at least three and not more than seven members.
Each member of the credit committee shall be appointed from among the members of the credit union.
Not more than one member of the credit committee may be a director.
The treasurer of the credit union may not be a member of the credit committee.
At least one member of the credit committee shall have a minimum of 3 years experience in lending, credit, or general business.
Each member of the credit committee:

subparagraph.text: Shall be a member of the credit union for the period of time required under the bylaws;
Shall be bonded;
May not have defaulted on the payment of any monetary obligation to the credit union;
May not have been convicted of any criminal offense involving dishonesty or breach of trust;
May not have habitually neglected to pay any debts;
May not have been insolvent or bankrupt within 5 years of becoming a member and may not become insolvent or bankrupt while serving as a member; and
May not have been removed by the Commissioner or any state or federal regulatory agency as an officer, official, or employee of a financial institution.

subsection.text: A member of the credit committee serves for 1 year and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The credit committee shall fill any vacancy on the committee by appointing an individual to serve until the next regular meeting of the board.
The members of the credit committee shall elect the chairman of the credit committee at the beginning of each term and at any other time that a vacancy may occur in the position of the chairman.
The board shall remove any member of the credit committee who fails:

paragraph.text: To attend three consecutive regular meetings of the credit committee without good cause; or
To perform any of the duties of the office.

subsection.text: Each member of the credit committee shall take an oath to perform faithfully the duties of the office.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, and in § 6-328 (7) and (8) of this title, a loan may not be made to any member of a credit union unless it is approved unanimously by those members of the credit committee who are present at a meeting that is attended by a majority of the members of the credit committee.
If the bylaws of the credit union so provide, an applicant for a loan that is not approved by the credit committee may appeal to the board of directors.

subparagraph.text: The credit committee or the president may appoint loan officers.
The appointment of loan officers by the president shall be subject to confirmation by the credit committee.
The credit committee shall supervise loan officers and delegate to them the power to approve or disapprove loans in accordance with written instructions or policies adopted by the board.

paragraph.text: Not more than one loan officer may be a member of the credit committee.
A loan made by a loan officer in accordance with the written instructions or policies of the board does not have to be approved by the credit committee.

subparagraph.text: Each loan officer shall give the credit committee the record of each loan that the officer approves or disapproves within 7 days after a loan application is made.
The credit committee shall act on each loan application where the decision of the loan officer has been appealed by the credit union member.

paragraph.text: A loan officer may not disburse credit union funds for any loan that the loan officer approved.

subsection.text: The credit committee shall meet as often as necessary.

section.text: The total of all loans made by a credit union directly or indirectly to any one member may not exceed 10 percent of the total assets of the credit union.

subsection.text: A credit union may make a loan, including a business loan, to a member with or without security in accordance with the written lending policies established by the board that cover all secured and unsecured loans.
A credit union may accept as security for a loan:

paragraph.text: An endorsed note;
A note secured by a lien on real, leasehold, or personal property;
An assignment of shares or deposits in the credit union; or
Any other kind of security that is approved by the Commissioner.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may review the lending policies of the credit union and order changes.
A credit union may make a loan to a member that is secured by real or leasehold property in accordance with written real estate lending policies established by the board as provided in this section.
A loan under this section shall be:

paragraph.text: Secured by a deed of trust or mortgage on real or leasehold property; and
Amortized over a period of 30 years or less.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may review the lending policies of the credit union and order changes.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to an extension of credit or loan made by a credit union on or after October 1, 1994.

A loan under this section that is secured by a first mortgage may be made at any rate of interest that does not exceed the rate authorized by Title 12, Subtitle 1 of the Commercial Law Article for mortgage loans.
A loan under this section that is secured by a second mortgage may be made at any rate of interest that does not exceed the rate authorized by Title 12, Subtitle 4 of the Commercial Law Article.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, a credit union may participate with a depository financial institution or a credit union service organization for purposes of making a loan to a credit union member in accordance with the lending policies of the board.

A credit union may participate in a loan under subsection (a) of this section provided that the credit union that originates the loan retains an interest of at least 10% of the face amount of the loan.

section.text: A credit union may make a loan that is insured or guaranteed by the federal government, a state government or local government, or a unit of the federal government or of any state or local government.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Eligible obligation” means a loan or a group of loans made to a member of a credit union by a lender other than the credit union to which the member belongs.
“Student loan” means a loan that is:

subparagraph.text: Granted to finance the borrower’s attendance at an institution of higher education or at a vocational school; and

Secured by, and on which payment of the outstanding principal and interest has been deferred in accordance with, the insurance or guarantee of the federal government, a state government, or a unit of the federal government or of a state government.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, a credit union may purchase, in whole or in part, in accordance with the board’s purchase policies:

subparagraph.text: Eligible obligations of its members;
Eligible obligations of the individual members of a liquidating credit union, from the liquidating credit union;

Student loans if the credit union is granting student loans on an ongoing basis and if the purchase will facilitate the credit union’s packaging of a pool of the loans to be sold or pledged on the secondary market; and

Real estate loans if the credit union is granting real estate loans under this subtitle on an ongoing basis and if the purchase will facilitate the credit union’s packaging of a pool of the loans to be sold or pledged on the secondary mortgage market.

paragraph.text: A credit union may make a purchase under paragraph (1) of this subsection if:

subparagraph.text: The board or investment committee approves the purchase;
A written agreement and a schedule of the eligible obligations covered by the agreement are retained by the credit union for inspection;
The aggregate of the unpaid balance of eligible obligations purchased under paragraph (1)(i) and (ii) of this subsection does not exceed 5% of the total assets of the credit union; and
For purchases of real estate loans under paragraph (1)(iv) of this subsection, the pool of loans to be sold or pledged on the secondary mortgage market:

sub-subparagraph.text: Includes a substantial portion of the credit union’s members’ real estate loans, but no less than 20% of the aggregate principal amount of the loans purchased; and
Is sold promptly, but no later than 6 months after the purchase.

subsection.text: A credit union may sell or pledge, in whole or in part, the eligible obligations or loans purchased under subsection (b)(1) of this section if:

paragraph.text: The board or investment committee approves the sale or pledge; and
The written agreement covering the sale or pledge and a schedule of the eligible obligations or loans covered by the agreement are retained by the credit union for inspection.

subsection.text: A credit union may agree to service any eligible obligation the credit union purchases or sells in whole or in part.

paragraph.text: A credit union may make a loan to an official of the credit union if the official takes no part in consideration of the loan application.
A loan authorized under paragraph (1) of this subsection requires approval of the board if:

subparagraph.text: The official is the debtor in the loan or is the guarantor, endorser, or cosigner of the loan; and

The loan, standing alone or when added to the aggregate of all outstanding loans for which the official is the debtor or acts as guarantor, endorser, or cosigner, or both, exceeds $25,000 plus pledged shares.

subsection.text: The rates, terms, and conditions on any loan from a credit union to, or guaranteed, endorsed, or cosigned by, an official or officer of the credit union may not be more favorable than the rates, terms, and conditions for a comparable loan to another member of the credit union.

section.text: A credit union may not make a loan to any person except:

paragraph.text: A member of the credit union;
Another credit union; or
A credit union service organization.

subsection.text: Each credit union incorporated under the laws of this State shall:

paragraph.text: Participate in and have its member accounts insured under the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program; or

Participate in and have its member accounts insured by a credit union share guaranty corporation that is approved by the Commissioner to at least the same extent and amount as provided by the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program.
The Commissioner may examine any credit union share guaranty corporation that insures the member accounts of a credit union that is subject to this title.
The Commissioner may charge the reasonable cost of an examination conducted under paragraph (1) of this subsection to the credit union share guaranty corporation that is examined.

subsection.text: A credit union share guaranty corporation, its members, and persons who have share and deposit accounts in credit unions are not subject to the provisions of the Insurance Article as a result of any of the activities of the credit union share guaranty corporation under this title.

A credit union may not voluntarily terminate its insurance with the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program or a credit union share guaranty corporation without prior approval of the Commissioner.

section.text: A credit union is subject to the provisions of 12 C.F.R., Part 702 (Prompt Corrective Action) and 12 U.S.C. § 1790d (Net Worth Provisions).

subsection.text: In this section, “risk assets” means a credit union’s total loans outstanding to its members.

paragraph.text: Each credit union shall have a reserve fund to meet losses on loans and to meet other contingencies that the Commissioner specifies.
The reserve fund may be distributed to the members of the credit union only on dissolution of the credit union.
After paying organization expenses, each credit union shall credit to its reserve fund all entrance fees, transfer fees, and fines.
A credit union in operation for 4 years or more and having assets of $500,000 or more shall credit to the reserve fund, at the end of each accounting period:

subparagraph.text: 10 percent of its gross income until the reserve fund equals 4 percent of its risk assets; and
Then, 5 percent of its gross income until the reserve fund equals 6 percent of its risk assets.

paragraph.text: A credit union in operation for less than 4 years or having assets of less than $500,000 shall credit to the reserve fund, at the end of each accounting period:

subparagraph.text: 10 percent of its gross income until the reserve fund equals 7.5 percent of its risk assets; and
Then, 5 percent of its gross income until the reserve fund equals 10 percent of its risk assets.

paragraph.text: On recommendation of the board, the amount credited to the reserve fund may be increased.

subsection.text: If the reserve fund falls below the amounts required by subsection (c)(2) or (3) of this section, it shall be restored by regular contributions.
A credit union shall maintain an allowance for loan and lease loss account in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
The balance of the allowance for loan and lease loss account shall include coverage for:

paragraph.text: Individually classified loans; and
The historical reserve needs of the credit union.

subsection.text: The assets of a credit union that are not committed for loans may be invested in:

paragraph.text: General obligations of or obligations guaranteed by the United States;
Deposits, loans, shares, or stock of any federal reserve bank, federal home loan bank, or any central liquidity facility established under state or federal law;
Securities, obligations, or other instruments of or issued by or fully guaranteed as to principal and interest by the federal government or a unit of the federal government;

General obligations of a state or a federal territory or political subdivision, provided that the general obligation is rated in one of the three highest rating categories of a nationally recognized statistical rating organization as determined by the Commissioner;
Deposits or federal funds of any financial institution that has federal deposit insurance;
Shares or deposits of other credit unions;
Mutual funds that invest solely in investments permissible for direct investment by the credit union;
Repurchase transactions secured by investments permissible for direct investment by the credit union; or
Any other investment that the Commissioner approves.

Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, in addition to the investments authorized under subsection (a) of this section, a credit union may request authority from the Commissioner to make other investments, including investments authorized under the federal Credit Union Act or regulations of the National Credit Union Administration, on an ongoing basis.
To obtain the Commissioner’s approval for additional investment authority under paragraph (1) of this subsection, a credit union shall submit to the Commissioner an investment policy.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may review the investment policies of the credit union and order changes.

paragraph.text: With the prior approval of the Commissioner, as required under subsection (b) of this section, a credit union may organize a credit union service organization.
A credit union that proposes to organize a credit union service organization shall:

subparagraph.text: File with the Commissioner a notice of intention to organize a credit union service organization; and
Submit to the Commissioner any information the Commissioner requires in order to evaluate the proposed credit union service organization.

paragraph.text: In deciding whether to approve the organization of a credit union service organization, the Commissioner shall consider whether:

subparagraph.text: The organization of the credit union service organization will promote the convenience of the members of the credit union;
The credit union has sufficient net worth to support the credit union service organization; and
The credit union generally is operating in compliance with the provisions of this title.

paragraph.text: Unless the Commissioner notifies the credit union that a different time period is necessary, within 60 days of receipt of the notice specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Commissioner shall notify the credit union of the determination on the approval of the organization of a credit union service organization.
Subject to the provisions of this subsection, a credit union may invest in and make loans to a credit union service organization.

If an investment or loan by a credit union to a credit union service organization causes the aggregate of the credit union’s investments or loans to exceed 2% of the credit union’s total assets, the credit union shall:

subparagraph.text: Notify the Commissioner as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection; and
Receive the prior approval of the Commissioner for any investment in or loan to the credit union service organization that exceeds the limit imposed under this paragraph.

paragraph.text: A credit union that proposes to make any investment in or loan to the credit union service organization that exceeds the limit under paragraph (2) of this subsection shall:

subparagraph.text: File with the Commissioner a notice of intention to exceed the limit; and
Submit to the Commissioner any information the Commissioner requires in order to evaluate the proposed intention to exceed the limit.

paragraph.text: In deciding whether to approve the investment or loan, the Commissioner shall consider whether:

subparagraph.text: The investment or loan will promote the convenience of the members of the credit union;
The credit union has sufficient net worth to support the investment or loan; and
The credit union generally is operating in compliance with the provisions of this title.

paragraph.text: Unless the Commissioner notifies the credit union that a different time period is necessary, within 60 days of receipt of the notice specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Commissioner shall notify the credit union of the determination on the approval of the investment or loan.

subsection.text: As deemed necessary by the Commissioner, the Commissioner shall have complete:

paragraph.text: Access to the books and records of a credit union service organization; and
Authority to review the internal controls of a credit union service organization.

subsection.text: A credit union service organization may serve on a contractual basis more than one credit union and its members.

paragraph.text: In addition to any other investment authorized under this subtitle, a credit union may purchase, construct, or acquire and hold, either individually or jointly with another credit union, fixed assets for the purpose of providing adequate facilities for the transaction of present and future business.
A credit union may use fixed assets acquired under this section for:

subparagraph.text: The principal office functions;
Branches; and
Any other activities in which the credit union engages.

paragraph.text: A credit union may rent excess space in a fixed asset acquired under this section as a source of income.
A credit union’s investment in fixed assets acquired under this section:

subparagraph.text: May exceed 4% of the total assets of the credit union only with the prior approval of the Commissioner; and
May not exceed 6% of the total assets of the credit union.

subsection.text: A credit union may purchase, lease, or acquire and hold tangible personal property, either individually or jointly with another credit union, as may be necessary or incidental to the operations of the credit union.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, a credit union may borrow money for the purchase of fixed assets.
The term of the loan may not exceed:

subparagraph.text: 15 years for borrowings secured by real or leasehold property; and
5 years for borrowings secured by other fixed assets.

subsection.text: A credit union may borrow money for a purpose other than the purchase of fixed assets as long as the total borrowing does not exceed the greater of:

paragraph.text: Two times the net worth of the borrowing credit union; or
10% of the total assets of the borrowing credit union.

section.text: A credit union may change its place of business on written notice to the Commissioner.
The fiscal year of each credit union ends at the close of business on December 31.

subsection.text: A credit union shall post its hours of operation prominently in its office.
Each credit union shall be open for business during its posted hours, except that a credit union may close:

paragraph.text: On any State holiday; and
At any other time if:

subparagraph.text: Notice of the closing is posted prominently in its office 3 business days in advance;
Specifically authorized to close by the Commissioner; or
An emergency exists that affects the credit union and it is not practical to obtain authorization from the Commissioner before closing the affected credit union.

subsection.text: If a credit union closes under the provisions of subsection (b)(2)(iii) of this section, the chairman of the board or the president of the affected credit union shall notify the Commissioner of the reason for the closing of the credit union as soon as possible but no later than 24 hours after the closing of the credit union.
This section applies only to a credit union with assets of $300,000 or greater.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall impose an annual assessment on each credit union as provided in this subsection to cover the expense of regulating credit unions.
The Commissioner shall assess each credit union the sum of:

subparagraph.text: 8 cents for each $1,000 of the assets of the credit union over $1,000,000.

paragraph.text: The assessment shall be based on assets stated in the credit union’s most recent financial report.

subsection.text: A credit union shall pay the assessment imposed under this section to the Commissioner on or before the March 1 after the assessment is imposed.

section.text: If a credit union files an application with the Maryland Insurance Commissioner to purchase or make available, as an agent or otherwise, insurance for its members either on an individual or group basis, the credit union shall notify the Commissioner, within 10 days after filing the application, that the credit union has filed the application.

subsection.text: As approved by the Commissioner, a credit union may enter into marketing arrangements with a person to facilitate the credit union’s members’ voluntary purchase of goods or other services from third parties, consistent with the purposes of the credit union.
A credit union may be compensated for the services provided under subsection (a) of this section.
A credit union shall keep the books and records that the Commissioner requires to determine compliance with this title.
Unless a longer period is expressly required by State or federal law, a credit union shall retain the books and records required under subsection (a) of this section for a period of at least 5 years.
A credit union may retain the books and records required under subsection (a) of this section at any location, provided that the credit union:

paragraph.text: Notifies the Commissioner in writing of the location of the books and records; and

Makes the books and records available at the credit union’s principal place of business, as agreed by the Commissioner and the credit union, within 7 days of a written request for examination by the Commissioner.

subsection.text: A credit union shall retain the books and records required under subsection (a) of this section in one of the following ways:

paragraph.text: Original form;
An electronic equivalent approved by the Commissioner; or
A microphotographic copy approved by the Commissioner.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Eligible credit union member” means an individual member of a credit union who:

subparagraph.text: Maintains a qualifying share certificate account at a credit union participating in a savings promotion raffle;
Is a member in good standing;
Is an adult; and
Is a resident of this State.

paragraph.text: “Qualifying share certificate account” means a savings account, savings program, or other time deposit offered to an eligible credit union member.
“Savings promotion raffle” means a contest:

subparagraph.text: Associated with one or more qualified share certificate accounts;
Conducted by a credit union, alone or together with other businesses; and
In which eligible credit union members are offered one or more chances to win specified prizes.

subsection.text: Subject to the approval of the Commissioner, a credit union may conduct a savings promotion raffle for the exclusive benefit of eligible credit union members if:

paragraph.text: A requirement for a chance to win a specified prize is:

subparagraph.text: The deposit of a minimum specified amount of money in a qualifying share certificate account according to the terms and conditions developed for the savings promotion raffle; or
The submission of an entry according to the terms and conditions developed for the savings promotion raffle with no deposit or purchase necessary;

paragraph.text: Each entry in the savings promotion raffle has an equal chance of being drawn;
The credit union maintains books and records relating to the savings promotion raffle; and
The savings promotion raffle will not:

subparagraph.text: Harm the credit union’s ability to operate in a safe and sound manner; or
Mislead the credit union’s members.

subsection.text: A credit union offering a savings promotion raffle under this section shall post in any location where entries may be submitted and disclose in any materials promoting the raffle a statement describing the terms and conditions of the raffle including that:

paragraph.text: No purchase is necessary;
Making deposits or purchasing goods or services will not improve the odds of winning; and
The odds of winning will be determined based on the number of entries received.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: Examine the conduct of a savings promotion raffle; and
Issue a cease and desist order under § 6–906 of this title for a violation of this section.

subsection.text: Any State credit union may convert into a federal credit union as provided by federal law and as provided in this section.
A majority of the board of a credit union proposing to convert shall:

paragraph.text: Adopt a resolution that declares that the conversion is advisable;
Set a date for a vote on the proposed conversion by the members of the credit union at an annual or special meeting of the members or by mail ballot to be filed on or before that date;
Comply with federal law regarding conversion; and
File the required conversion application with the Commissioner.

subsection.text: The Commissioner, at the request of the board, may:

paragraph.text: Waive the vote of the members; and
Substitute any reasonable method of determining the approval by the members.

subsection.text: Unless the Commissioner takes action under subsection (c) of this section, written notice of the proposed conversion and of the date set for the vote shall be delivered in person to each member or mailed to each member at the member’s address as recorded by the credit union, not more than 30 days nor less than 7 days before the date set for the vote.

paragraph.text: Unless the Commissioner takes action under subsection (c) of this section, the proposed conversion shall be approved by the affirmative vote of a majority of the members who vote on the proposal.

Within 10 days after the vote, a statement of the results of the vote shall be filed with the Commissioner. The statement shall be verified by the chairman or vice chairman of the board and by the secretary of the credit union.
Within 90 days after a proposed conversion is approved by the members, the credit union shall take any action necessary under federal law to make it a federal credit union.

Within 10 days after the credit union receives a federal credit union charter, a copy of that charter shall be filed with the Commissioner and, when the copy is filed, the credit union ceases to be a State credit union.

subsection.text: When the conversion from a State credit union to a federal credit union is complete:

paragraph.text: The converted credit union is no longer subject to the provisions of this title; and
The successor federal credit union owns all the assets and is responsible for all the obligations of the former State credit union as though the conversion had not taken place.

subsection.text: Any credit union organized under the laws of any other state or of the United States may convert to a State credit union as provided in this section.
A credit union proposing to convert shall meet:

paragraph.text: All of the requirements of this title for the incorporation of a credit union in this State; and
All of the requirements of the Commissioner, including any specific conditions that a credit union must meet in order to convert.

subsection.text: A majority of the board of a credit union proposing to convert shall:

paragraph.text: Adopt a resolution that declares that the conversion is advisable; and
Set a date for a vote on the proposed conversion by the members at an annual or special meeting of the members or by mail ballot to be filed on or before that date.

subsection.text: The Commissioner, at the request of the board, may:

paragraph.text: Waive the vote of the members; and
Substitute any reasonable method of determining the approval by the members.

subsection.text: Unless the Commissioner takes action under subsection (d) of this section, written notice of the proposed conversion and of the date set for the vote shall be delivered in person to each member or mailed to each member at the member’s address as recorded by the credit union, not more than 30 days nor less than 7 days before the date set for the vote.

paragraph.text: Unless the Commissioner takes action under subsection (d) of this section, the proposed conversion shall be approved by the affirmative vote of a majority of the members who vote on the proposal.

Within 10 days after the vote, a statement of the results of the vote shall be filed with the Commissioner. The statement shall be verified by the chairman or vice chairman of the board and the secretary of the credit union.
A credit union may convert to a State credit union if:

subparagraph.text: The converted credit union:

sub-subparagraph.text: Meets the common bond requirements of the proposed field of membership type; and
Files with the Commissioner an application and any other documents that the Commissioner deems necessary to make a determination; and

subparagraph.text: The Commissioner determines that the conversion:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is in the best interest of the existing and proposed membership;
Will likely result in better service to the existing membership;
Is in accordance with sound credit union practices; and
Does not expose the funds of the existing members to unnecessary risk.

paragraph.text: Unless the Commissioner notifies the credit union that a different time period is necessary, within 120 days after the application is filed, the Commissioner shall notify the credit union of the determination on the application.

subsection.text: When the conversion is complete, the successor credit union owns all of the assets and is responsible for all the obligations of the credit union as though the conversion had not taken place.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Merging credit union” means a credit union that is absorbed or acquired by another credit union in a merger and ceases to exist after the merger.
“Surviving credit union” means a credit union that absorbs or acquires another credit union in a merger and continues to exist after the merger.
“New credit union” means a credit union that is created when two or more credit unions consolidate to form a newly created credit union.

subparagraph.text: With the approval of the Commissioner, any credit union may merge or consolidate as provided in this section.
A merger or consolidation under this section may be with a credit union organized under the laws of the United States, this State, or any other state.

A single common bond credit union may merge or consolidate with another single common bond credit union resulting in a surviving or new single common bond credit union provided that the credit unions party to the merger or consolidation share the same single common bond, as defined under § 6-301(c)(2) of this title, prior and subsequent to the merger or consolidation.
A single common bond credit union may merge or consolidate with another single common bond credit union resulting in a surviving or new multiple common bond credit union provided that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Prior to the merger or consolidation, one of the credit unions converts into a multiple common bond credit union, as provided under § 6-304 of this title, which includes in its field of membership the group served by the other single common bond credit union; and
The surviving or new multiple common bond credit union satisfies the requirements for multiple common bonds under § 6-301(c)(3) and (e) of this title.

paragraph.text: A single common bond credit union may merge or consolidate with a multiple common bond credit union resulting in a surviving or new multiple common bond credit union provided that:

subparagraph.text: Prior to the merger or consolidation, the multiple common bond credit union includes or adds to its field of membership the group served by the single common bond credit union, as provided under § 6-303 of this title; and
The surviving or new multiple common bond credit union satisfies the requirements for multiple common bonds under § 6-301(c)(3) and (e) of this title.

paragraph.text: A multiple common bond credit union may merge or consolidate with another multiple common bond credit union resulting in a surviving or new multiple common bond credit union provided that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Prior to a merger, the credit union that will become the surviving credit union includes or adds to its field of membership the groups served by the credit union that will become the merging credit union, as provided under § 6-303 of this title; or
In the case of a consolidation, the field of membership of the new credit union includes all groups that will be served by that new credit union; and

subparagraph.text: The surviving or new multiple common bond credit union satisfies the requirements for multiple common bonds under § 6-301(c)(3) and (e) of this title.

paragraph.text: A single or multiple common bond credit union may merge, as the merging credit union, with a community credit union, as the surviving credit union, provided that:

sub-subparagraph.text: The merging credit union has a branch within the community boundaries of the surviving credit union; or
A majority of the members in the field of membership of the merging credit union would qualify for membership in the surviving credit union;

subparagraph.text: No less than 30 days before the effective date of the merger, the merging credit union gives notice of the merger to all groups of potential members of the merging credit union that will be removed from the field of membership as a result of the merger; and
On and after the effective date of the merger, the surviving credit union:

sub-subparagraph.text: May not continue to serve groups within the field of membership of the merging credit union that are located outside the community boundaries of the surviving credit union; and
May continue to serve members of a group identified under item 1 of this paragraph who are members before the effective date of the merger.

paragraph.text: A community credit union may merge or consolidate with another community credit union provided that:

subparagraph.text: The members of the surviving or new credit union remain within a single well-defined local community, neighborhood, rural district, or county; and
The surviving or new credit union is within reasonable geographic proximity to the members of the credit union party to the merger or consolidation.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraphs (8) and (9) of this subsection, a community credit union may not merge, as a merging credit union, with a single or multiple common bond credit union.

Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (2), (3), (4), or (5) of this subsection or the numerical limitations prescribed in § 6-301(e) of this title, the Commissioner may approve the merger or consolidation of any credit union with a multiple common bond credit union, as a new or surviving credit union, when safety and soundness concerns are present as determined by the Commissioner.

Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraphs (2) through (8) of this subsection, the Commissioner may approve the merger or consolidation of any credit union, whether or not the credit unions party to the merger or consolidation have the same field of membership type, if:

subparagraph.text: Any of the credit unions party to the merger or consolidation is insolvent or likely to become insolvent;
The merger or consolidation is in the best interest of the membership of the credit unions party to the merger or consolidation; and
The merger or consolidation will not adversely affect the financial condition of the surviving or new credit union.

paragraph.text: If the surviving or new credit union will be a State credit union:

subparagraph.text: The merger or consolidation shall be made in accordance with the provisions of this subtitle; and
If one of the credit unions is a federal credit union, federal law governs its actions and the rights of its members.

paragraph.text: If the surviving or new credit union will be a federal credit union:

subparagraph.text: The merger or consolidation shall be made in accordance with federal law which governs its actions and the rights of its members; and
The merger or consolidation shall be made in accordance with the provisions of this subtitle for a State credit union and the rights of its members.

paragraph.text: If the surviving or new credit union will be another State credit union:

subparagraph.text: The merger or consolidation shall be made in accordance with the provisions of this subtitle for the State credit union and the rights of its members; and
The merger or consolidation shall be made in accordance with the provisions of the other State laws for the other State credit union and the rights of its members.

subsection.text: A majority of the board of each credit union proposing a merger or consolidation shall:

paragraph.text: Adopt a resolution that declares that the merger or consolidation is advisable; and

Set a date for a vote on the proposed merger or consolidation by the members of each credit union party to the merger or consolidation at any annual or special meeting of the membership or by mail ballot to be filed on or before that date.

subsection.text: The Commissioner, at the request of the board, may:

paragraph.text: Waive the vote of the members; and
Substitute any reasonable method of determining the approval by the members.

subsection.text: The merger or consolidation shall be in accordance with a plan that:

paragraph.text: States the field of membership type that the surviving or new credit union will have;
Is agreed to by a majority of the board of each credit union party to the merger or consolidation; and

Unless provided otherwise by the Commissioner, is approved by the members of each credit union party to the merger or consolidation, by the affirmative vote of a majority of the members of each credit union party to the merger or consolidation who vote on the proposal.

After agreement by the board and approval by the members of each credit union party to the merger or consolidation, two officers of each credit union party to the merger or consolidation shall execute a certificate of merger or consolidation.
The certificate of merger or consolidation shall include as to each credit union party to the merger or consolidation:

subparagraph.text: The time and place of the meeting of the board at which the plan was agreed to;
The vote by which the plan was agreed to by the board;
A copy of the resolution or other action by which the plan was agreed to by the board;
The date on or by which the plan was approved by the members of each credit union; and
Unless provided otherwise by the Commissioner, the vote by which the plan was approved by the members of each credit union.

paragraph.text: A credit union may merge or consolidate if:

sub-subparagraph.text: The surviving or new credit union meets the common bond requirements of the proposed field of membership type; and
Each credit union party to the merger or consolidation files with the Commissioner:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: The certificate of merger or consolidation;
A copy of the plan of merger or consolidation; and
Any other documents that the Commissioner deems necessary to make a determination on the application; and

subparagraph.text: The Commissioner determines that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Each credit union party to the merger or consolidation has not engaged in any material unsafe or unsound practice during the 1-year period preceding the date of filing of the certificate of merger or consolidation;
The surviving or new credit union has adequate net worth;

The surviving or new credit union has the administrative capability to serve the members of the surviving or new credit union and the financial resources to meet the need for additional staff and assets to serve the surviving or new credit union; and

Any potential harm that the surviving or new credit union may have on any other credit union and its membership is clearly outweighed, in the public interest, by the probable beneficial effect of the merger or consolidation in meeting the convenience and needs of the members of the surviving or new credit union.

paragraph.text: Unless the Commissioner notifies the credit union that a different time period is necessary, within 60 days after the certificate of merger or consolidation is filed, the Commissioner shall:

subparagraph.text: Notify each credit union party to the merger or consolidation of the determination on the application; and
