Certify the certificate of merger or consolidation and return the certificate to each credit union party to the merger or consolidation.

subsection.text: When the certificate is certified and sent back to the credit unions by the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: All of the property, property rights, and members’ interest of the credit unions party to the merger or consolidation belong to the surviving or new credit union without deed, endorsement, or other instrument of transfer;
All of the debts, obligations, and liabilities of the credit unions party to the merger or consolidation are assumed by the surviving or new credit union; and
The rights and privileges of the members of the credit unions party to the merger or consolidation remain intact.
The surviving or new credit union shall act promptly to file and record the certified certificate and plan of merger or consolidation with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
When the certificate and plan of merger or consolidation are filed with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation, the merger or consolidation takes effect.

subsection.text: Any credit union may dissolve voluntarily, if the board, the members of the credit union, and the Commissioner approve the dissolution as provided in this section.
A majority of the board of a credit union proposing to dissolve shall adopt a resolution that:

paragraph.text: Recommends that the credit union be dissolved voluntarily; and
Directs that a proposal of dissolution be submitted to the members.
A proposed dissolution shall be approved at an annual or special meeting of the members or by mail ballot by the affirmative vote of two-thirds of the entire membership of the credit union.
The Commissioner may substitute any reasonable method of determining the vote of the members.

subsection.text: After a proposed dissolution is approved by the members, the credit union shall file with the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: A copy of the resolution of the board recommending voluntary dissolution, attested to by:

subparagraph.text: The chairman or vice chairman of the board; and
The secretary or treasurer of the credit union;

paragraph.text: A verified statement of the names and addresses of the officers and directors of the credit union; and
The vote by which the voluntary dissolution was approved by the members.

If the Commissioner finds that the credit union is solvent, the Commissioner shall issue to the credit union duplicate certificates stating that the credit union appears to have complied with this section.
The credit union shall file one of the certificates with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

subsection.text: When the certificate is filed with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation, the credit union is dissolved.

paragraph.text: On dissolution, a credit union may operate only to wind up its business and affairs.
Under the direction of the Commissioner, the liquidating agent of the dissolved credit union, appointed by the board, shall:

subparagraph.text: Discharge its debts and obligations;
Collect and distribute its assets; and
Do anything else necessary to wind up its business and affairs.

paragraph.text: For 3 years after the dissolution becomes effective, the credit union, acting by its board and liquidating agent:

subparagraph.text: Shall continue in existence for the purpose of winding up its business and affairs; and
May sue and be sued in its name.

subsection.text: Any credit union voluntarily may place its business and assets in the hands of the Commissioner for liquidation as provided in this section.
A majority of the board proposing a voluntary receivership shall:

paragraph.text: Adopt a resolution that declares that the voluntary receivership is advisable; and
Set a date for a vote on the proposed voluntary receivership by the members of the credit union at an annual or special meeting of the members or by mail ballot to be filed on or before that date.

subsection.text: The Commissioner, at the request of the board, may:

paragraph.text: Waive the vote of the members; and
Substitute any reasonable method of determining the approval by the members.

subsection.text: Unless the Commissioner takes action under subsection (c) of this section, the proposed voluntary receivership shall be approved by the affirmative vote of a majority of the members of the credit union who vote on the proposal.

After the action is approved by the members, the proper officers of the credit union shall certify the action of the members to the Commissioner, and the Commissioner shall post a notice at each office of the credit union that states: “This credit union is in the hands of the Maryland Commissioner of Financial Regulation for liquidation.”

If a credit union is placed in the hands of the Commissioner under this section, the Commissioner shall place the credit union in receivership for liquidation in the same manner as provided for a banking institution under Title 5, Subtitle 6 of this article.

section.text: With the approval of the Commissioner, a credit union may purchase the assets or assume the liabilities of another credit union whether or not the credit unions have the same field of membership type, if:

paragraph.text: The other credit union is insolvent or likely to become insolvent;
The purchase or assumption is in the best interest of the membership of the other credit union; and
The purchase or assumption will not adversely affect the financial condition of the credit union that makes the purchase or assumption.

subsection.text: A credit union may establish a branch in the State in accordance with the provisions of this section.

paragraph.text: A credit union that proposes to establish a branch in the State shall:

subparagraph.text: File with the Commissioner, at least 30 days before the intended opening date, a notice of intention to open a branch;
Submit to the Commissioner any information the Commissioner requires in order to evaluate the proposed branch; and
Pay to the Commissioner a branch fee of $100.

paragraph.text: The branch fee may not apply to a branch that is acquired by a credit union through a merger or consolidation with, or transfer to the credit union of all or substantially all of the assets of, a credit union.

subsection.text: In deciding whether to approve the establishment of a branch, the Commissioner shall consider whether:

paragraph.text: The establishment of the branch will promote the convenience of the members of the credit union;
The applicant has sufficient net worth to support the branch; and
The applicant generally is operating in compliance with the provisions of this title.
The Commissioner shall decide whether to approve the establishment of a branch within 30 days of receipt of the notice specified in subsection (b)(1) of this section.
The establishment of a branch shall be deemed approved if the Commissioner takes no action on the notice within the time limit specified in this subsection.

subsection.text: An out-of-state credit union shall provide the Commissioner, within 15 days of opening a branch in the State, with a notice of the opening of the branch.

A credit union chartered and primarily regulated by another state that proposes to establish a branch in this State shall qualify under § 7-203 of the Corporations and Associations Article to do business in the State as a foreign corporation.
An out-of-state credit union that has a branch in this State may establish additional branches in this State:

paragraph.text: To the same extent as a credit union; or
To the extent otherwise permitted by federal law.

subsection.text: A credit union may require not more than 60 days’ notice of a member’s intention to withdraw from a share account or deposit account.
A requirement imposed under subsection (a) of this section shall:

paragraph.text: Apply to all members of the credit union; and
Be included in each member’s account agreement.
Except for a credit union authorized to do business in this State, a person may not:

subparagraph.text: Use or advertise any name or title that contains the words “credit union” or any derivation of that term;
Represent itself as a credit union;
Conduct business as a credit union; or
Conduct business under a name or title that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Indicates or reasonably implies that the person engages in or transacts the type of business conducted by a credit union; or
Is calculated to lead a person to believe that the business engaged in or transacted is the type of business conducted by a credit union.

paragraph.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $3,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both per occurrence.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to an association or league of credit unions, whether or not the association or league is incorporated.

A person may not willfully make, circulate, or send to another person any untrue statement that is derogatory to the financial condition or that affects the solvency or financial standing of any credit union doing business in the State, or counsel, aid, procure, or induce another to make, circulate, or send to another person such a statement.
A person that violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or both.

An officer, official, or employee of a credit union may not willfully and knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or false entry in the records of the credit union or, with the intent to deceive a person authorized to examine the affairs of the credit union, sign or exhibit false records.

An officer, official, or employee who violates any provision of this section is guilty of a felony and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 10 years or both.

An officer or official who in any way knowingly permits or participates in making a loan in violation of § 6-611 of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $3,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both, per occurrence.
If a loan is made in violation of § 6-611 of this title, the credit union may recover the amount of the loan from:

paragraph.text: Any borrower; or
Any officer or official who knowingly permitted or participated in making the loan.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may order a credit union, or enter into an agreement with a credit union, to take corrective action if the Commissioner finds that the credit union:

paragraph.text: Has failed to file a report when due;
Is insolvent;
Has violated any provision of this title; or
Is engaged in an unsafe or unauthorized practice.
Before the order becomes effective, the Commissioner shall give the credit union an opportunity for a hearing.
Notice of the hearing shall be given and the hearing shall be held in accordance with Title 10 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner determines that the violation or practice under subsection (a) of this section requires immediate action to protect depositors or members, the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: May issue a cease and desist order that is effective on service; and
Shall give the credit union an opportunity for a hearing to rescind the order.

subsection.text: If the credit union fails to comply with the order within 60 days after it becomes effective, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: Take possession of the business and assets of the credit union and operate it until the Commissioner permits it to resume business or until the Commissioner orders its liquidation under item (3) of this subsection;

Order the credit union share guaranty corporation that insures the credit union to take possession of the business and assets of the credit union and operate it in accordance with the Commissioner’s instructions until the Commissioner permits it to resume business or until the Commissioner orders its liquidation under item (3) of this subsection; or
Place the credit union in receivership for liquidation in the same manner as provided for a banking institution under Title 5, Subtitle 6 of this article.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall order any credit union to cease and desist from:

paragraph.text: An unsafe or unsound practice;
A practice that is injurious to the public interest; or
A violation of laws or rules or regulations that relate to the Commissioner’s supervision of the credit union.

subsection.text: To protect depositors or members, the Commissioner may include in a cease and desist order a restriction on the withdrawal of money from any credit union.
The Commissioner may include in a cease and desist order a requirement that the officers or officials act affirmatively to correct any violation or practice.

paragraph.text: Before a cease and desist order takes effect, the Commissioner shall give the credit union an opportunity for a hearing.
Notice of the hearing shall be given and the hearing shall be held in accordance with Title 10 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner determines that the violation or practice under subsection (a) of this section requires immediate action to protect depositors or members, the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: May issue a cease and desist order that is effective on service; and
Shall give the credit union an opportunity for a hearing to rescind the order.

subsection.text: After notice and a hearing, the Commissioner may assess a civil penalty against a credit union that the Commissioner determines has:

paragraph.text: Violated a cease and desist order issued by the Commissioner under § 6–906 of this subtitle; or
Engaged in:

subparagraph.text: An unsafe or unsound practice; or
A practice that is injurious to the public interest.

subsection.text: The civil penalty may not exceed:

paragraph.text: $1,000 per violation; and
$1,000 per violation for each day that the violation continues.
A civil penalty shall be assessed by written notice of assessment served on the person to be assessed.
The notice of assessment shall state the:

subparagraph.text: Amount of the civil penalty;
Legal authority for the assessment; and
Matters of fact or law constituting the grounds for the assessment.

paragraph.text: The notice of assessment shall constitute a final order for purposes of judicial review pursuant to § 10–221 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: In determining the amount of the civil penalty to be assessed, the Commissioner shall consider:

paragraph.text: The seriousness of the violation;
The good faith of the violator;
The violator’s history of previous violations;
The deleterious effect of the violation on the public and the credit union industry;
The assets of the violator; and
Any other factors relevant to the determination of the civil penalty.
A civil penalty assessed under this section shall be due and payable within 30 days after the Commissioner issues the notice of assessment.
The Commissioner may reduce or set aside a civil penalty.

subsection.text: The Commissioner shall pay all civil penalties collected under this section into the General Fund of the State.
In this section, “extraordinary circumstances” means a situation presenting specific concerns about the prompt withdrawal of money from, or the safety and soundness of, a credit union.

In extraordinary circumstances and with the consent of the credit union, the Commissioner may close to the public a hearing concerning the assessment of a civil penalty, an order to cease and desist, or any other formal enforcement action by the Commissioner.

paragraph.text: If the Commissioner believes that an officer or official has engaged in an unsafe or unsound practice, the Commissioner shall send a warning to the officer or official.

If the Commissioner finds that the officer or official has continued to engage in the unsafe or unsound practice, the Commissioner may report the facts to the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation and the Attorney General.
A copy of the report shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, bearing a postmark from the United States Postal Service, to each director of the credit union.

If the Commissioner finds that the unsafe or unsound practice continues after the warning and the officer, official, agent, or employee was provided an opportunity to be heard, the Commissioner may remove the officer, official, agent, or employee with the approval of the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
Notice of the hearing shall be given and the hearing shall be held in accordance with Title 10 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: A copy of the removal order shall be served on the individual removed and the credit union.
If the Commissioner determines that the unsafe or unsound practice under subsection (a) of this section requires immediate action to protect depositors or members, the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: May issue a cease and desist order that is effective on service; and
Shall give the officer or official an opportunity for a hearing to rescind the order.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner believes that any officer, official, agent, or employee of a credit union has violated any provision of this title, the Commissioner may report the violation directly to the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation and to the Attorney General who shall take the appropriate steps to institute a prosecution for the violation.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner shall send a written warning to an officer, official, agent, or employee of a credit union who the Commissioner believes has violated any provision of this title.
If after a warning the violation continues, the officer, official, agent, or employee may be removed as provided in § 6-907(b) of this subtitle.

Unless otherwise specified, any officer, official, agent, or employee of a credit union who violates the provisions of this title is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $3,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years.

subsection.text: If the Commissioner determines that the violation under subsection (a) of this section requires immediate action to protect depositors or members, the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: May issue a cease and desist order that is effective on service; and
Shall give the officer, official, agent, or employee an opportunity for a hearing to rescind the order.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this article, the Commissioner and the employees of and the attorney for the Commissioner’s office may not disclose:

paragraph.text: The name of any debtor of a credit union;
Any information about the private accounts with or transactions of a credit union;
Any information obtained in the course of examining a credit union; or
Any confidential information obtained from a credit union authority.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to any information that a person discloses:

paragraph.text: In performing a public duty to report on or take special action about the business of a credit union;
In testifying as a witness in a criminal proceeding; or
In informing any official, officer, employee, or agent of a credit union under examination of the results of that examination.
The Commissioner may give a credit union share guaranty corporation information about a credit union if:

subparagraph.text: The credit union is insured by the credit union share guaranty corporation; or
The credit union:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is applying for insurance from the credit union share guaranty corporation; and
Requests the Commissioner to provide the information.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may give the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program information about a credit union if:

subparagraph.text: The credit union is insured by the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program; or
The credit union:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is applying for insurance from the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program; and
Requests the Commissioner to provide the information.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, all confidential information disclosed to any person as permitted under this section:

paragraph.text: Remains the property of the Commissioner; and
May not be further disclosed by that person without the written permission of the Commissioner.

subsection.text: A person that violates any provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: Forfeiture of the person’s office or employment; and
A fine not exceeding $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or both.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Corporation” means the Credit Union Insurance Corporation.
“Credit union” means:

paragraph.text: Any credit union that is incorporated under the laws of this State; and
Any other credit union that is authorized to do business in this State and has its principal office in this State.

subsection.text: There is a Credit Union Insurance Corporation, established as a nonprofit, nonstock corporation, the members of which are credit unions that are accepted for membership under this part.

paragraph.text: The Corporation is not and may not be deemed a department, unit, agency, or instrumentality of the State for any purpose.

All debts, claims, obligations, and liabilities of the Corporation, whenever incurred, shall be the debts, claims, obligations, and liabilities of the Corporation only and not of the State, its agencies, instrumentalities, officers, or employees.
The Corporation moneys may not be considered part of the General Fund of the State.
The debts, claims, obligations, and liabilities of the Corporation may not be considered to be a debt of the State or a pledge of its credit.

section.text: The purposes of the Corporation are to:

paragraph.text: Insure and guarantee the share and deposit accounts of member credit unions;
Improve and stimulate the ability of credit unions to provide low-cost consumer loans;
Promote the elasticity and flexibility of the resources of credit unions;
Make loans for liquidity purposes to credit unions;
Discount notes of credit unions;
Provide a State service of lending among credit unions;
Help rehabilitate and stabilize credit unions;
Help liquidate credit unions in an orderly manner when necessary;
Help strengthen and develop credit unions serving low-income individuals; and

Cooperate with and assist credit unions, organizations of credit unions, the Commissioner, the National Credit Union Administration, and others in improving the general welfare of the people through credit unions.

subsection.text: The Corporation exercises its powers and performs its duties subject to the authority of the Commissioner.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the Corporation has all of the powers, privileges, and immunities granted to Maryland corporations under the Maryland General Corporation Law.
Subject to the provisions of Part III of this subtitle, the Corporation has perpetual existence.
The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: Lend money to any credit union;
Guarantee, endorse, or act as surety on the obligations of or otherwise assist financially any credit union; and
Establish and regulate the terms and conditions of and charges for any loans or financial assistance to credit unions.
The Corporation may buy, lease, or otherwise acquire and sell, mortgage, lease, or otherwise dispose of real or personal property on the terms that its Board of Directors considers advisable.
The Corporation may acquire any real or personal property in satisfaction of debts or enforcement of obligations and may dispose of that property.

subsection.text: The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: Assist in the merger, stabilization, consolidation, or liquidation of credit unions; and
Take possession of and operate the business and assets of any credit union if ordered to do so by the Commissioner under § 6-905 of this article.

subsection.text: The Corporation may become a member of the National Association of Share Insurance Corporations or any comparable organization.
The Corporation may invest any of its funds in:

paragraph.text: Cash or deposits in checking or savings accounts with or certificates of deposit of:

subparagraph.text: Any bank that is a member of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation; and
Any savings and loan association whose deposits are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation;

paragraph.text: Cash or deposits in share or deposit accounts with or certificates of deposit or notes of any credit union that is a member of the Corporation, the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program, or a similar insurance program;
Obligations of:

subparagraph.text: The United States or any state or any political subdivision of any state;
Any commission, instrumentality, agency, or authority of the United States or any state; and
Any corporation that is incorporated under the laws of the United States or of any state;

paragraph.text: Readily marketable, dividend-paying shares of any corporation that is incorporated under the laws of the United States or of any state, except that it may not invest more than 10 percent of its total assets in these shares nor more than 3 percent of its total assets in the shares of any one corporation; and
Any other investments, including common trust investments, that are permitted by law or authorized by the Commissioner for credit unions.

subsection.text: The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: Borrow money and otherwise incur obligations for any of its purposes;
Issue its secured or unsecured bonds, debentures, notes, or other evidences of obligation; and
Secure these obligations by mortgage, pledge, or other lien on all or any part of its property, rights, and privileges.

subsection.text: The Corporation shall insure and guarantee the share and deposit accounts of each member on the same basis, and to the same extent and amount as provided by the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program.
The Corporation may make contracts for reinsurance.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of Part III of this subtitle, any credit union may apply to the Corporation to become a member of the Corporation.
The Corporation shall refer each application that it receives to the Commissioner.
On receipt of an application for membership, the Commissioner shall examine the affairs of the credit union.
If the Commissioner finds that the credit union qualifies for membership under § 7–107 of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall certify that fact to the Corporation.

subsection.text: The Corporation may not extend benefits to any credit union until the Corporation receives the certification of the Commissioner.

paragraph.text: A credit union becomes a member of the Corporation when:

subparagraph.text: The financial affairs, solvency, and management of a credit union have been certified by the Commissioner as approved for insurance of its share and deposit accounts; and
The application of the credit union is accepted by the Board of Directors of the Corporation.

paragraph.text: The Board of Directors of the Corporation may deny the application of a credit union only for good cause shown.

subsection.text: Subject to the bylaws, rules, and regulations of the Corporation and except as provided in subsection (c) of this section and Part III of this subtitle, membership in the Corporation continues as long as the Corporation exists.

paragraph.text: If the Board of Directors of the Corporation finds that unsafe or unsound practices or mismanagement of a member threatens loss to the Corporation or appears to affect adversely the solvency of the member, the Board may:

subparagraph.text: Order the member to correct the situation; or
With the approval of the Commissioner and after giving the member notice and an opportunity for a hearing, revoke the membership of the credit union.

paragraph.text: A credit union that is organized under federal law or the laws of any other state may withdraw from the Corporation by:

subparagraph.text: Giving written notice at least 1 year in advance; and
Complying with the bylaws, rules, and regulations of the Corporation.

subsection.text: Each member of the Corporation shall make the investments and pay the assessments, premiums, and other charges required for participation in the Corporation.
In the election of directors and in voting on any other matter at a meeting of the members of the Corporation, each member has one vote, to be cast by its delegate.
A delegate may not vote on behalf of more than one member.
A majority of the votes cast is sufficient to elect directors or decide any questions voted on by the members.
The powers of the Corporation shall be exercised by its Board of Directors.
The Board of Directors consists of 11 directors elected by the members of the Corporation.
Each director shall be a resident of this State.

paragraph.text: Each director serves for a term of 4 years and until a successor is chosen and qualifies.
The terms of the directors shall be staggered as required by the terms provided for directors on July 1, 1988.

If a vacancy occurs as to an elected director, the Board of Directors shall elect a successor to fill the vacancy until the next annual meeting of the members of the Corporation. At the annual meeting, the members of the Corporation shall elect a successor to serve for the rest of the term and until a successor is elected and qualifies.

subsection.text: A majority of the full authorized membership of the Board of Directors is a quorum.
Each director is entitled to reasonable compensation, as set by the Board of Directors with the approval of the Commissioner.

paragraph.text: The Board of Directors of the Corporation:

subparagraph.text: Shall elect one of its members as chairman of the Board; and
May appoint any officers and employees that it considers advisable.

paragraph.text: The manner of election of the chairman and appointment of officers and their terms of office shall be as the bylaws provide.

subsection.text: In accordance with the bylaws of the Corporation, the Board of Directors shall set the amount of the fidelity bonds of the officers and employees of the Corporation.
The Board of Directors of the Corporation shall adopt bylaws for the Corporation and rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this title.

paragraph.text: A bylaw, rule, or regulation becomes effective only after it is submitted to and approved by the Commissioner.

A bylaw, rule, or regulation is considered approved if the Commissioner does not notify the Corporation of disapproval and the reasons for it within 30 days after submission of the bylaw, rule, or regulation.
The Commissioner may disapprove a bylaw, rule, or regulation only if the Commissioner has reason to believe that:

subparagraph.text: It is contrary to the principles or purposes of this title; or
It does not serve the best interests of the public.

section.text: The Corporation may require independent audits and investigations of any member to determine the member’s financial condition as it relates to insurance of share and deposit accounts. These audits and investigations shall be made at the expense of the credit union.

subsection.text: This section applies notwithstanding any other provisions of law.

paragraph.text: The Corporation and the Commissioner may exchange information about credit unions.
The Commissioner shall make available to the Corporation all examinations of credit unions that are members of the Corporation.

subsection.text: If a credit union is not incorporated under the laws of this State, the credit union may not be accepted as a member of the Corporation unless it submits a written statement from the agency that regulates it stating that the agency will cooperate with the Commissioner in carrying out the provisions of this title.

section.text: The net earnings of the Corporation shall be accumulated and may not be returned to its members.

The Corporation, its members, and persons who have share and deposit accounts in credit unions are not subject to the provisions of the Insurance Article as a result of any of the activities of the Corporation under this title.

The Corporation is exempt from all taxes imposed by this State or any of its political subdivisions under Title 9 of Article 24 of the Code, Title 6, Subtitle 1 of the Insurance Article, the Tax - General Article, or the Tax - Property Article.
This title does not, and the Corporation may not, pledge the faith or credit of this State.

subsection.text: The Corporation may not accept an application from a credit union for new membership on or after the date that the Commissioner issues the first certificate of authority under § 7-203 of this title.
The Commissioner shall notify the Corporation of the date that the Commissioner issues the first certificate of authority under § 7-203 of this title.
A credit union that is a member of the Corporation shall obtain primary share guaranty insurance with:

paragraph.text: The National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program; or

A credit union share guaranty corporation regulated under Subtitle 2 of this title that is approved by the Commissioner to provide primary share guaranty insurance at least to the same extent and amount as provided by the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program.

subsection.text: A credit union that is a member of the Corporation shall comply with the provisions of subsection (a) of this section within 2 years after the date that the Commissioner issues the first certificate of authority under § 7-203 of this title.

paragraph.text: In this section, “assets” means:

subparagraph.text: All net earnings of the Corporation accumulated under § 7–114 of this subtitle; and
All real or tangible or intangible personal property of the Corporation.

paragraph.text: In this section, “assets” does not include member deposits.

subsection.text: Within 2 years after the date that the Corporation no longer has any members, the Corporation shall complete the dissolution of the Corporation in accordance with the provisions of this section.

paragraph.text: When the Corporation no longer has any members, the Corporation shall file articles of dissolution with the Commissioner and the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the Corporation is dissolved when the Commissioner accepts the Corporation’s articles of dissolution.

The Corporation continues to exist for the purpose of collecting money owing to the Corporation, paying, satisfying, and discharging any existing debts or obligations, collecting and distributing the Corporation’s assets, and doing all other acts required to liquidate and wind up the business and affairs of the Corporation.

After paying, satisfying, and discharging any existing debts or obligations, the Corporation shall transfer its remaining assets to a corporation that satisfies the requirements of subsection (e) of this section.

subsection.text: The corporation receiving the assets under subsection (d)(2) of this section shall:

paragraph.text: Be a nonprofit corporation that is exempt from federal taxation under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code;
Have been organized:

subparagraph.text: For educational and charitable purposes; and
To promote and publicize the interest and welfare of credit unions and their members in this State; and

paragraph.text: Have been in existence and operating under a charter that includes the following purposes for at least 10 years:

subparagraph.text: Promoting the ideals of the credit union movement, including the cooperative nonprofit aspect, democratic aspect, the common bond, volunteerism, personalized service, cooperative spirit, and the encouragement of thrift and the creation of a source of credit at fair and reasonable rates;
Helping to strengthen and develop credit unions serving low–income individuals;
Improving and stimulating the ability of credit unions to provide low–cost consumer loans;
Promoting the elasticity and flexibility of the resources of credit unions;
Conducting or funding research on all aspects of credit union operations and the credit union movement in general;
Cooperating and assisting credit unions and local and national organizations and credit unions to improve the general welfare of the people through credit unions;
Providing scholarships and awards to professionals and volunteers in the credit union movement; and
Furthering the credit union movement and performing all necessary and properly related services and activities.

subsection.text: The Corporation shall promptly notify the Commissioner following the completion of the liquidation and the winding up of the business and affairs of the Corporation.

section.text: The Commissioner may require the Corporation to provide any information that the Commissioner deems necessary to determine whether the phase-out and dissolution of the Corporation are in accordance with the provisions of this part.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
Unless the context requires otherwise, “credit union” has the meaning stated in § 6-101(d) of this article.
“Credit union share guaranty corporation” means a corporation that is:

paragraph.text: Engaged in the business of providing primary share guaranty insurance for the share and deposit accounts of a credit union; and
Regulated under this subtitle.

subsection.text: “Participating credit union” means a credit union that has applied for and been admitted to participation in a credit union share guaranty corporation and whose participation has not terminated.

section.text: The provisions of this subtitle do not apply to the Credit Union Insurance Corporation established under Subtitle 1 of this title.

subsection.text: A person may not conduct business as a credit union share guaranty corporation unless the person has a certificate of authority issued by the Commissioner under this subtitle.
A certificate of authority issued by the Commissioner under this subtitle is not transferrable.

A credit union share guaranty corporation shall insure and guarantee the share and deposit accounts of each participating credit union to at least the same extent and amount as provided by the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program.
A credit union share guaranty corporation may make contracts for reinsurance.
To qualify for a certificate of authority under this subtitle, an applicant shall satisfy the Commissioner that the applicant:

paragraph.text: Is trustworthy and reputable;
Has a good business reputation;
If domiciled outside the State, is currently licensed and authorized to engage in the credit union share guaranty business in its state of domicile;
Has and will maintain retained earnings or equity capital of at least $5,000,000, computed in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
Is in compliance with:

subparagraph.text: Its charter and this subtitle; and
If domiciled outside the State, all laws and regulations applicable to credit union share guaranty corporations in its state of domicile;

paragraph.text: Will conduct the credit union share guaranty business in the State in a manner that will adequately protect the share and deposit accounts of its participating credit unions; and
Will maintain reserves for guaranty losses in compliance with § 7-217 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person may not be authorized to engage in the credit union share guaranty business in the State if the person has or uses a name that is so similar to the name of a credit union share guaranty corporation already issued a certificate of authority under this subtitle as to tend to cause uncertainty or confusion or to deceive or mislead.

paragraph.text: To apply for a certificate of authority, an applicant shall sign and submit to the Commissioner an application made under oath on the form that the Commissioner requires.
The application shall include:

subparagraph.text: The applicant’s corporate name, business address, and any trade names under which the applicant conducts business;
The name and business address of each of the applicant’s officers and directors;
The address at which the business is to be conducted;
The name and address of the applicant’s proposed resident agent in the State; and
Any other information that the Commissioner reasonably requires.

subsection.text: With the application, the applicant shall submit:

paragraph.text: A certified copy of its articles of incorporation with all amendments;
A certified copy of its bylaws with all amendments;

A copy of the applicant’s annual financial statements as of the immediately preceding December 31, prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and audited and certified by an independent certified public accountant;
If domiciled outside the State, a copy of the applicant’s most recent report of examination, if any, made by the responsible supervisory official in its state of domicile;

If domiciled outside the State, certification by the responsible supervisory official in its state of domicile showing that the applicant is authorized to engage in the credit union share guaranty business in that state;
A copy of the applicant’s current standard written contract with participating credit unions containing the rights and obligations of the parties; and
Any other information and documents that the Commissioner reasonably requires.

subsection.text: With the application, the applicant shall pay to the Commissioner a nonrefundable application fee of $5,000.

When an applicant for a certificate of authority files the application and pays the application fee required under § 7-206 of this subtitle, the Commissioner shall conduct an investigation to determine if the applicant meets the requirements of § 7-205 of this subtitle.

Unless the Commissioner notifies the applicant that a different time period is necessary, the Commissioner shall approve or deny each application for a certificate of authority within 120 days after the complete application is filed and the application fee is paid.
The Commissioner shall issue a certificate of authority to any applicant who meets the requirements of this subtitle.
If an application for a certificate of authority is denied, the notification of the denial shall:

paragraph.text: Be in writing; and
State the applicant’s right to a hearing held in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.

subsection.text: An applicant who seeks a hearing on an application denial shall file a written request for a hearing within 30 days following receipt of the notice of the applicant’s right to a hearing.

The Commissioner may suspend or revoke the certificate of authority of a credit union share guaranty corporation if the credit union share guaranty corporation or a director or officer of the credit union share guaranty corporation:

paragraph.text: Makes a material misstatement in an application for a certificate of authority;
Is convicted under the laws of the United States or any state of:

subparagraph.text: A felony; or
A misdemeanor that is directly related to the activities authorized by the certificate of authority;

paragraph.text: In connection with any credit union share guaranty transaction:

subparagraph.text: Commits a fraud;
Engages in an illegal or dishonest activity; or
Misrepresents or fails to disclose a material fact to a person entitled to that information;

paragraph.text: Violates any provision of this subtitle, any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle, or any other law regulating credit union share guaranty business in the State, or fails to comply with an order of the Commissioner;

Is found by the Commissioner to be in unsound condition or in a condition that renders further transaction of credit union share guaranty business hazardous to participating credit unions, the members of the participating credit unions, or the public;
Refuses or delays payment of amounts due claimants without just cause;
Refuses to be examined or to produce records or files for examination by the Commissioner when required;
Refuses to provide additional information reasonably requested by the Commissioner; or

Otherwise demonstrates unworthiness, bad faith, dishonesty, or any other quality that indicates that the business of the credit union share guaranty corporation has not been or will not be conducted honestly, fairly, and equitably.

subsection.text: In determining whether the certificate of authority of a credit union share guaranty corporation should be suspended or revoked for a conviction listed in subsection (a)(2) of this section, the Commissioner shall consider:

paragraph.text: The nature of the crime;
The relationship of the crime to the activities authorized by the certificate of authority;
The relevance of the conviction to the fitness and qualification of the credit union share guaranty corporation to engage in the credit union share guaranty business;
The length of time since the conviction; and
The behavior and activities of the credit union share guaranty corporation since the conviction.
The Commissioner may enforce the provisions of this subtitle and any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle by:

subparagraph.text: Issuing an order to the credit union share guaranty corporation or entering into an agreement under which the credit union share guaranty corporation agrees:

sub-subparagraph.text: To cease and desist from the violation and any further similar violations; and
To take affirmative action to correct the violation, including the restitution of money or property to any person aggrieved by the violation; and

subparagraph.text: Imposing a civil penalty not exceeding $1,000 for each violation.

paragraph.text: If a violator fails to comply with an order or agreement under this subsection, the Commissioner may impose a civil penalty not exceeding $1,000 for each violation from which the violator failed to cease and desist or for which the violator failed to take affirmative corrective action.

subsection.text: The Commissioner may file a petition in the circuit court for a county seeking enforcement of an order issued under this section.
In determining the amount of financial penalty to be imposed under subsection (c) of this section, the Commissioner shall consider:

paragraph.text: The seriousness of the violation;
The good faith of the violator;
The violator’s history of previous violations;
The deleterious effect of the violation on the public and holders of credit union share or deposit accounts;
The assets of the violator; and
Any other factors relevant to the determination of the financial penalty.
Before the Commissioner takes any action under subsection (a) or (c) of this section, the Commissioner shall give the credit union share guaranty corporation an opportunity for a hearing.
A hearing under this subtitle shall be held in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act.

The hearing notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the credit union share guaranty corporation to the principal place of business of the credit union share guaranty corporation at least 30 days before the hearing.
The Commissioner:

subparagraph.text: Shall examine the business of each credit union share guaranty corporation at least once every 24 months; and
May examine the business of each credit union share guaranty corporation at any time that the Commissioner reasonably considers necessary.

paragraph.text: The Commissioner may enter into agreements with third parties and delegate the authority to conduct an examination required or permitted under this subsection.

In lieu of performing an examination of a credit union share guaranty corporation, the Commissioner may accept an examination report from the responsible supervisory official of the credit union share guaranty corporation’s state of domicile.

A person aggrieved by the conduct of a credit union share guaranty corporation under this subtitle in connection with the credit union share guaranty business may file a written complaint with the Commissioner who may investigate the complaint.

The Commissioner may make any other investigation of any person if the Commissioner has reasonable cause to believe that the person has violated any provision of this subtitle, any regulation adopted under this subtitle, or any other law regulating credit union share guaranty corporations in the State.

subsection.text: In connection with an examination or investigation made under this section, the Commissioner may:

paragraph.text: Examine the books and records of any credit union share guaranty corporation or of any other person who the Commissioner believes has violated any provision of this subtitle, any regulation adopted under this subtitle, or any other law regulating credit union share guaranty corporations in the State;
Subpoena documents or other evidence; or
Summon and examine under oath any individual whose testimony the Commissioner requires.

subsection.text: If any person fails to comply with a subpoena or summons issued by the Commissioner under this section, the Commissioner may file a petition for enforcement in the appropriate circuit court.
A credit union share guaranty corporation shall pay all reasonable expenses for transportation, lodging, and meals associated with:

paragraph.text: An examination required or permitted under § 7-210 of this subtitle; and
Any other examination or investigation conducted under this article that results in the discovery of a violation of this subtitle by the credit union share guaranty corporation.
A credit union share guaranty corporation shall pay an annual assessment of $5,000.
A credit union share guaranty corporation shall pay the assessment imposed under paragraph (1) of this subsection to the Commissioner on or before February 15 after the assessment is imposed.

On or before April 1 of each year, unless the Commissioner extends the time for good cause, each credit union share guaranty corporation shall file with the Commissioner an annual report for the immediately preceding calendar year.
The annual report shall include:

subparagraph.text: The annual financial statement of the credit union share guaranty corporation prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and audited and certified by an independent certified public accountant that contains:

sub-subparagraph.text: A balance sheet;
An income statement;
A statement of cash flows;
A statement of changes of the credit union share guaranty corporation’s equity; and
Notes to the financial statement;

subparagraph.text: The following information regarding all participating credit unions, as appropriate, regardless of the state in which a participating credit union is domiciled:

sub-subparagraph.text: The composite CAMEL rating of each credit union if the composite CAMEL rating of a credit union is 4 or 5; and

Any current administrative action or any current plan for corrective action concerning each credit union initiated by the credit union share guaranty corporation or the responsible supervisory official in the credit union’s state of domicile; and

subparagraph.text: An analysis of the components of the guaranty fund required under § 7-216 of this subtitle, including any reserves for guaranty losses established under § 7-217 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Unless the Commissioner extends the time for filing, a credit union share guaranty corporation that fails to file an annual report on or before April 10 shall pay a penalty of $100 for each day from April 1 to the day before the Commissioner receives the report.

subsection.text: At any time, the Commissioner may require a credit union share guaranty corporation to file an interim report containing the information that the Commissioner considers necessary.
This section applies notwithstanding any other provision of law.

A credit union share guaranty corporation and the Commissioner may exchange information, including information obtained during an examination, about a participating credit union or a credit union that is applying for participation in the credit union share guaranty corporation.

The Commissioner may exchange information, including information obtained during an examination, about a credit union share guaranty corporation with any state or federal agency having supervisory authority over the credit union share guaranty corporation.
A credit union share guaranty corporation shall have a written contract with each participating credit union that clearly establishes the rights and obligations of the parties.

At least 30 days before the effective date of any material amendment to the standard written contract that is submitted under § 7-206(b) of this subtitle, the credit union share guaranty corporation shall file the amendment with the Commissioner.

section.text: A credit union share guaranty corporation shall provide written notice to the Commissioner of:

paragraph.text: The receipt from a credit union of an application for participation in the credit union share guaranty corporation;
The credit union share guaranty corporation’s underwriting decision regarding the application for participation; and
The voluntary or involuntary termination of the participation of a credit union in the credit union share guaranty corporation.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a credit union share guaranty corporation shall establish and maintain a guaranty fund of at least 1 percent of the aggregate shares and deposits of the participating credit unions.

A credit union share guaranty corporation that is domiciled outside the State may maintain a guaranty fund at the level permitted by its state of domicile if the credit union share guaranty corporation:

subparagraph.text: Has been domiciled in that state for at least 25 years immediately preceding the date of the credit union share guaranty corporation’s completed application for a certificate of authority;

Has engaged in the credit union share guaranty business for at least 25 years immediately preceding the date of the credit union share guaranty corporation’s completed application for a certificate of authority; and
The business of the credit union share guaranty corporation is subject to regulation by its state of domicile.

subsection.text: The guaranty fund shall be comprised of the following:

paragraph.text: The account for each participating credit union;
Retained earnings; and
Any reserves established under § 7-217 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The amount of the account of each participating credit union shall be carried on the books of the participating credit union as an asset.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle, a credit union share guaranty corporation may require a participating credit union to make additional capital contributions to maintain the normal operating level during any calendar year in which the fund has been reduced below the minimum operating level as a result of payment of any deficiencies in credit union share accounts.

Within 60 days of the assessment, a credit union share guaranty corporation shall file with the Commissioner a report of each capital contribution that the credit union share guaranty corporation requires under subsection (d) of this section.

paragraph.text: If a participating credit union fails to pay an annual capital contribution, premium, fee, or assessment when due, the credit union share guaranty corporation:

subparagraph.text: Within 10 days after the failure, shall report the failure in writing to the Commissioner; and
After 30 days’ notice, may revoke the participating credit union’s participation in the credit union share guaranty corporation, unless good cause is shown for the failure.

paragraph.text: The 30-day notice of revocation required under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection does not apply to the revocation of excess coverage.

Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, a credit union share guaranty corporation shall refund to a participating credit union an amount equal to the balance of the participating credit union’s capital contribution account, less any outstanding debts owed to the credit union share guaranty corporation, if the participating credit union:

subparagraph.text: Voluntarily dissolves;
Obtains primary share guaranty insurance from the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program or another credit union share guaranty corporation regulated under this subtitle; or

Merges or consolidates with another credit union that results in the share and deposit accounts of the surviving or new credit union being insured by the National Credit Union Administration Share Insurance Program or another credit union share guaranty corporation regulated under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: A credit union share guaranty corporation shall make a refund under paragraph (1) of this subsection only if the guaranty fund equals or exceeds the guaranty fund’s normal operating level as calculated without the account of the exiting credit union.

subsection.text: If two or more participating credit unions merge or consolidate and the surviving or new credit union is to be insured by the credit union share guaranty corporation, the funds in the capital contribution account of each credit union shall be transferred to the account of the surviving or new credit union, less any outstanding debts owed to the credit union share guaranty corporation.

If a credit union share guaranty corporation is dissolved, the net assets after paying all liabilities and all costs of dissolution shall be distributed to the participating credit unions in accordance with their share and deposit balances, less any outstanding debts owed to the credit union share guaranty corporation.

paragraph.text: A credit union share guaranty corporation shall establish reserves for guaranty losses on an incurred basis in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles during the period in which the losses become evident.
The reserves shall provide for:

subparagraph.text: Losses reported to the credit union share guaranty corporation;
Losses incurred but not previously reported; and
Estimated losses on the collection of notes and other guarantees to participating credit unions.

subsection.text: The reserves shall be maintained until the losses for which the reserves were established have been satisfied.
The Commissioner shall give prompt notice to the applicable credit union share guaranty corporation whenever the Commissioner:

paragraph.text: Takes possession of the property and assets of a participating credit union; and
Determines to liquidate the property and assets of a participating credit union.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding the provisions of §§ 5-605 and 6-905(d) of this article, the Commissioner may petition a court of competent jurisdiction to appoint the applicable credit union share guaranty corporation as receiver of the participating credit union.

When the property and business of a participating credit union has been liquidated or is in the process of liquidation and the proceeds of liquidation distributed are insufficient to pay the full guaranteed amount of each credit union share or deposit account, the credit union share guaranty corporation shall pay each deficiency up to the guaranteed amount within 30 days after the date the credit union share or deposit account balance is verified.

When any participating credit union share or deposit account is paid, the credit union share guaranty corporation shall be subrogated to all rights of the member or depositor, up to the amount paid by the credit union share guaranty corporation to the member or depositor.
A credit union share guaranty corporation may terminate the participation of a participating credit union for any of the following reasons:

paragraph.text: The participating credit union fails to satisfy the risk eligibility standards established by the credit union share guaranty corporation and applicable to all participating credit unions;
The participating credit union operates in an unsafe and unsound manner as determined by the credit union share guaranty corporation;
The participating credit union fails to furnish financial statements, delinquent loan reports, or other information considered necessary by the credit union share guaranty corporation;

The participating credit union fails to remedy in a timely manner a qualification arising from an audit permitted or required under the written contract between the participating credit union and the credit union share guaranty corporation;
The participating credit union fails to pay when due a capital contribution or applicable premium, fee, or assessment under this subtitle;

The participating credit union fails to comply with any provision of this article or the articles of incorporation or bylaws of the credit union share guaranty corporation that are material to the safety and soundness of the participating credit union; or
Continued participation by the participating credit union would result in a violation of this subtitle or other applicable state or federal law by the credit union share guaranty corporation.
At least 30 days before the effective date of any termination, the credit union share guaranty corporation shall send written notice of the pending termination and the reasons for the termination to:

subparagraph.text: The participating credit union whose participation is to be terminated; and
The Commissioner.

paragraph.text: The 30-day notice required under paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to the termination of excess coverage.

section.text: A person who violates any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or both.
Nothing in this subtitle creates any liability on the State for the payment of any funds to any participating credit union or other person by reason of:

paragraph.text: An act or omission of a credit union share guaranty corporation; or
A deficiency of a participating credit union in the event a credit union share guaranty corporation is unable to pay the deficiency.

section.text: A credit union share guaranty corporation, its participating credit unions, and persons who have share or deposit accounts in the participating credit unions are not subject to the provisions of the Insurance Article as a result of any of the activities of the credit union share guaranty corporation under this subtitle.

A credit union share guaranty corporation that is a nonprofit corporation exempt from federal taxation under § 501(c)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code is exempt from all taxes imposed by the State or any of its subdivisions under:

paragraph.text: Article 24, Title 9 of the Code;
Title 6, Subtitle 1 of the Insurance Article;
The Tax - General Article; or
The Tax - Property Article.

section.text: The Commissioner may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this title and in Title 9, the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Affiliate” means any corporation, business trust, statutory trust, association, partnership, sole proprietorship, or other similar organization or person of which an association or any officer, director, or controlling person of an association, directly or indirectly:

paragraph.text: Owns or controls either a majority of the voting shares or controls in any manner the election of a majority of its directors, trustees, or other persons exercising similar functions; or
Otherwise controls the management of that organization.

subsection.text: “Control” means the ability of a person to direct the management or policies of an association or entity or elect a majority of a board of directors or the ownership of more than 10 percent of the outstanding shares of any class of securities of an association or interest in an entity.
“Controlling person” means any person or entity, acting directly or indirectly, individually or in concert with one or more other persons or entities, or through one or more subsidiaries, who:

paragraph.text: Owns, controls, holds with power to vote, or holds proxies representing 10 percent or more of the voting shares, rights, or interests of any association or corporation; or
Controls in any manner the election or appointment of a majority of the directors of that association or corporation.

subsection.text: “Division Director” means the Director of the Division of Savings and Loan Associations.
“Holding company” means any company or other entity which directly or indirectly controls any other company, or other entity.
“Immediate family” means a spouse, child, child’s spouse, parent, sibling, grandparent, or grandchild.
“Related entity” means an affiliate, holding company, or subsidiary of a savings and loan association.
“Savings and loan association” or “association” means, unless the context clearly requires otherwise, a corporation that is chartered under the laws of this State as a savings and loan association.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
“Subsidiary” means any company or other entity which is directly or indirectly controlled by any controlling person.
In Title 9 of this article and this title the policy of this State is to provide for:

paragraph.text: The protection of the interests of customers in savings and loan associations and the general public in the soundness and preservation of the industry;
The safety and soundness of the business of savings and loan associations;
The conservation of assets of savings and loan associations; and

Adequate rulemaking power and administrative discretion so that regulation and supervision of savings and loan associations may be flexible and readily responsive to changes in economic conditions and to changes in savings and loan priorities.

subsection.text: Title 9 of this article and this title embody standards to be observed by the Division Director in the exercise of the Director’s discretionary powers, in the adoption of regulations, in the examination and supervision of associations subject to Title 9, and in all matters of construction and application of Title 9 of this article and this title required for any determination or action of the Division Director.

section.text: Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Program Evaluation Act, the provisions of this subtitle relating to the Division of Savings and Loan Associations and relating to the regulation of savings and loan associations are of no effect and may not be enforced after July 1, 1992.
There is a Division of Savings and Loan Associations in the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation shall appoint the Division Director with the approval of the Governor and the advice and consent of the Senate.
The Division Director serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.

The Division Director shall have experience in State or national regulation or management of financial organizations, which may include service as a bank or savings and loan association director or officer.
The Division Director is entitled to the salary provided in the State budget.
The Division Director shall adopt regulations necessary to accomplish the policies set forth in § 8–102 of this title.

Without limiting the authority conferred by subsection (a) of this section, the Division Director may adopt regulations consistent with the provisions of this title and Title 9 of this article with respect to:

paragraph.text: Any powers conferred on the Division Director in this title and Title 9 of this article;
Reserve requirements;
Stock ownership and dividends;
Stock transfers (change of control);
Incorporators, controlling persons, directors, officers, employees, and agents of a savings and loan association;
Bylaws;
Related entities;
The structure of the office of the Division;
The operation, conduct, and management of savings and loan associations;
Withdrawable accounts, savings accounts and plans, and contracts for savings programs;
Loans and loan expenses, including underwriting procedures;
Investments;
Forms and definitions;
Types of financial records to be maintained by savings and loan associations;
Retention periods of various financial records of savings and loan associations;
Internal control procedures of savings and loan associations;
Chartering and branching;
Liquidations;
Mergers;
Conversions;
Reports which may be required by the Division Director;
Conflicts of interest;
Accounting rules;
Issuance of orders;
Removal of directors, officers, and employees;
Advertising; and
Enforcement remedies relating to limitations on interest rates on deposits.

subsection.text: Without limiting the authority conferred by subsection (a) of this section, directors and officers of savings and loan associations shall develop and implement, by December 31, 1989, written:

paragraph.text: Real estate appraisal policies; and
Procedures pertaining to the hiring and performance of real estate appraisers.

subsection.text: The procedures required under subsection (c)(2) of this section shall set forth specific factors to be considered by the savings and loan association’s directors and officers, including but not limited to:

paragraph.text: Whether the appraiser is licensed or certified under the Business Occupations and Professions Article; and
The real estate appraiser’s:

subparagraph.text: Professional education; and
Experience in real estate appraising.

subsection.text: Real estate appraisal policies and procedures shall be submitted by the savings and loan associations to the Division Director for review and approval.

The regulations adopted by the Division Director may include reasonable requirements and limitations on the types and amounts of investments, the manner of raising capital, and the nature and amounts of reserves, irrespective of their effects on free economic competition.

If the Division Director believes that a savings and loan association or any of its controlling persons, directors, officers, agents, or employees has violated any provision of this title or Title 9 that relates to the association, the Division Director immediately shall report the violation to:

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
The Governor; and
The Attorney General, who shall take the appropriate steps to institute an investigation or other appropriate action for the violation.

subsection.text: The Division Director may provide advisory opinions on conflicts of interest on request.
With the approval of the Secretary, the Division Director may appoint the staff provided in the State budget.

Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section or otherwise by law, the Division Director shall appoint and remove all personnel in accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.
The deputy director is in the management service of the State Personnel Management System.

section.text: Before taking office, the Division Director shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

subsection.text: The Division Director shall devote full time to the duties of the office.

The Division Director and staff may not be officers, directors, employees, auditors, agents of, or attorneys for, nor retained in any manner by, nor have any ownership interest or deposit whatsoever in, any savings and loan association or related entity.

The Division Director, Division staff, and members of the immediate families of the Division Director and Division staff, as defined in § 15-102 of the State Government Article may not accept, directly or indirectly, any gift, gratuity, or remuneration of any type from any savings and loan association or related entity or from any director, officer, controlling person, employee, or agent of any savings and loan association or related entity.

paragraph.text: The Division Director, Division staff, and members of the immediate families of the Division Director and Division staff as defined in § 15-102 of the State Government Article may not become indebted to any association or related entity that is subject to the jurisdiction of the Division Director.
Any person who violates any provision of this section is subject to forfeiture of that person's office or employment in addition to any other penalty prescribed by law.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, nothing in this section may be construed to affect any contractual obligation, including a savings account, in existence before January 15, 1986.

subparagraph.text: All contractual obligations, including savings accounts, in existence before January 15, 1986, and the corresponding dollar amounts shall be fully disclosed to the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.
The Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation shall file each disclosure with the State Ethics Commission.

subsection.text: For a period of 2 years after termination of employment with the Division of Savings and Loan Associations, if the Division Director or former deputy division director is employed by a Maryland savings and loan association or becomes a director, officer, attorney, or agent of a Maryland savings and loan association, that individual may not:

paragraph.text: Represent, formally or informally, the association in any judicial, administrative, or other proceeding in which:

subparagraph.text: The Division of Savings and Loan Associations is a party; and
The former Division Director or former deputy division director substantially participated;

paragraph.text: Participate in any application submitted to the Division for the Division's approval; or

Attempt to influence, or make any oral or written communication, on behalf of the association in any matter before the Division relating to the association in which the individual participated personally and substantially as Division Director or former deputy division director.

section.text: After notifying the Secretary, the Division Director may:

paragraph.text: Subpoena witnesses and administer oaths or affirmations in the examination of any controlling person, director, officer, employee, or agent of an association or related entity, or of any other person in relation to the affairs, transactions, and conditions of the association or related entity;
Require the production of records, books, papers, contracts, and other documents; and
Issue subpoenas duces tecum.

On June 30 of each year, or at the discretion of the Division Director or as circumstances warrant, the Division Director shall provide a written report to the Governor, the President of the Senate, the Speaker of the House of Delegates, and the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation on:

subparagraph.text: The operations of the Division Director’s office;
The condition of the savings and loan industry, including any violations of this subtitle or Title 9 of this article and the regulations adopted under those titles; and
As to the laws that the Division Director administers, amendments that the Division Director considers desirable.

paragraph.text: The report is confidential and is not subject to disclosure in accordance with the provisions of § 10-617 of the State Government Article.
On June 30 of each year, the Division Director shall submit a report to the General Assembly in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article describing:

subparagraph.text: The operations of the Division Director’s office;
The general condition of the savings and loan industry; and
Any recommended legislative changes.

paragraph.text: The report may include a summary of final enforcement actions taken by the Division Director but may not include pending investigations of violations of law reported under subsection (a) of this section.

section.text: Subject to the evaluation and reestablishment provisions of the Program Evaluation Act, the provisions of this subtitle relating to the Division of Savings and Loan Associations and relating to the regulation of savings and loan associations are of no effect and may not be enforced after July 1, 1992.

subsection.text: The Division Director may issue orders:

paragraph.text: To compel a savings and loan association or related entity to comply with its charter or bylaws, any applicable law, or any rule or regulation;

To direct a savings and loan association or related entity to cease and desist from any unsafe or unsound business practice including, but not limited to, unsound or unsafe interest rates, any practice injurious to the public interest, or any violation of State law or regulation relating to savings and loan associations; or

To direct a savings and loan association or related entity to remove any officer, director, or employee who has participated in or consented to any violation of law, regulation, or order relating to savings and loan associations, any unsafe or unsound business practice in the operation of the association, any insider loan not authorized by § 9-307 of this article, or any repeated violation of the association’s charter or bylaws.

subsection.text: An order issued by the Division Director under this section to a savings and loan association, or related entity shall:

paragraph.text: Be in writing and signed by the Division Director;
State the alleged violation in detail and the facts that constitute the violation;
Direct the association or related entity to discontinue the violation or to take the ordered remedial action; and
State that the association or related entity has a right to a hearing with respect to matters set forth in the order if it submits a request for hearing within 20 days of the date of the order.

subsection.text: Upon receipt of such request, a hearing shall be scheduled promptly before the Division Director or the Division Director’s designee and notice of the date, time, and place of the hearing shall be provided to the association, holding company, or subsidiary in writing by the Division Director.
An order shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, bearing a postmark from the United States Postal Service, to:

paragraph.text: The president of the savings and loan association or related entity at its principal office in this State; or
Whomever the association or related entity designates to the Division Director.

subparagraph.text: In addition to an order issued under subsection (a) of this section, the Division Director may issue an emergency order with respect to any matter set forth in subsection (a) of this section if the Division Director determines that the protection of depositors, members, or stockholders of the association or the protection of the public requires immediate corrective action.
Emergency orders shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: Be effective on receipt;
Specify the charges and a hearing date within 30 days; and
Notify the recipient that, upon application, a hearing to abate the order will be scheduled within 10 days.
